lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: So I’m gonna put the questions up in the chat. But only if you want to read ahead, I'm just gonna kind of go one by one. However, if you, if we end up answering more of them as we go along, then I won't go back, and we don't necessarily have to go through all of them, but I just want to have them there, and then I can look at the screen instead of looking at my paper here. So the first question for you all today is, what was your experience of using the school counselor care and support box? And the questions and parentheses are kind of there, if like I need to probe for more information. But just in case it's helpful for you to read. And feel free to just jump in.

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: Well, I was… didn't know what it was at first, and then I opened it. I was like, oh, this isn't… I know it says school counselor care box. But I'm like, maybe this is something for the kids. But then the more I dug into it, the more I saw a lot of things that I do with the kids. You know the grounding and the perspective taking all of those exercises. So I thought that was really nice, and listening to the…um I won’t jump ahead, but I thought it was great. And there were nice examples to start with. So it was nice to have post-it notes that I could put on my monitor and things like that and share them with my team, and they thought it was really important and cool too. So it was just neat to do the things that I teach my kids to do, and I don't normally do those things all the time.. I used to, and it's like… I don’t know, it just depends on your job. I'm a Middle School counselor,  I used to be an elementary, and I used to do it all the time myself. And now I’m middle school. It's crazy. At first participant 1 didn’t realize box was for personal use; liked the box and the contents; they envisioned how to use own box with children/work team (in addition to self); noted reduced self-care over time after switching jobs to middle school;

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, is the box…do you think the box would be more helpful to you in a middle school role or in an elementary school role? Or do you think it's relevant like across the board for you?

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: I think it's relevant as a school counselor. It helped remind me of the things that I did when I was in elementary as a school counselor. I think it's important to also… it would be nice to share it with teachers. Because they go through a lot of trauma themselves, and don't know how to deal with it, and then we have to be there to listen to them. So I think it's important for all ages. But I don't know….I just saw that as a foundational work. And then middle school these kids don't like, I feel like I’m rambling…But the middle school kids don't employ these coping skills. And you can teach them…They just don't…. “That's dumb. I don't want to do that” I said: “But you need coping skills.” Participant 1 notes that box is relevant to the work counselors do, reminds them of work they did with children; Notes that ththe box would be relevant for teachers who go through trauma without knowing how to deal with it; says that students tend to resist using these necessary coping methods.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, Absolutely. Thanks, Kris. What about you, Evan?

lines.speaker: Participant 2
lines.text: It's also. This is my first year actually as a middle school guidance counselor. I have the seventh grade. So this has been a huge, huge learning experience for me this year. I think a lot of the stuff that I found in the School Counselor Box is very relevant to what I do on a daily basis with my students, like Kris was saying before…the post-it notes, everything like the research tools that I found in there to use just to reinforce with my students as they come into my office on a daily basis, have all been beneficial to the work that I do with my students. So I didn't have any ..like surprise reactions. I guess I would say I knew that they would be useful tools that I would be using on a daily basis that I found in that box. I think we received that at the School counselor Appreciation breakfast, which was back in February at the Hilton in West Palm Beach. So I'm grateful for the fact that I was given these tools to use with my students, and I was excited when I opened it and took the stuff out. So that's basically my reactions that I had to the box. Participant 2 had a huge learning experience as a new counselor; Says box is relevant to work with students and is useful; applies box to working with students rather than self, was grateful for the box

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That's what you know like…I think that LSIS wants to hear. I'm happy to hear it too. But I think that they want you to…they want to hear people like the box. But if not, they want to know how to make the box better, so feel free to also share suggestions when we get down to those questions too. Great. Oh, you know I didn't have you introduce each other, or you introduce yourselves to each other..do you know each other by chance? I know this is all Palm Beach people.

lines.speaker: Participant 2
lines.text: I don't. I work at Congress Middle School in Boynton Beach. I'm not sure where Kris works.

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: I’m at Polo Park Middle. So we’re on the opposite end. You’re south and I’m north. I’m central. So, yeah.

lines.speaker: Participant 2
lines.text: okay

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Awesome. Sorry about that, guys. It's also 7 o’clock for me, too, but thank you..I have a 2 year old and an infant who's born in January, so I joke that i'm not sure what day or time it is right now. Anyway, so the second question is, what did you, or was there anything that you learned from the box that you didn't know before?

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: No, not really. I've been in education for a while. I've been in school counseling for a while, and I’ve done a lot of professional development. I'm not from Florida. I'm From Washington State. So we do a lot of trainings for school counselors. Which I'm just being honest, It was very difficult coming to Florida, because there's not a lot of mental health until Stoneman Douglas happened. And that was my thought. And so I mean, yeah, I just want to say It wasn’t like I knew everything but everything that was in that box I pretty much already knew. Participant 1 has a lot of professional development and experience leading her to know about the information in the box; mentioned they struggled transitioning to working in Florida because there wasn’t a lot of mental health in FL for a while. 32

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, that’s good to know. That’s helpful to know. For you, before we go to Evan, maybe…what information was the most helpful? Or was there information that wasn't helpful?

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: Well, I like the video because it gave examples, and that were very layman's terms. And I like how she talked about this is, you know, people go through this, and just step by step, and the book helped as well. But everything else is.. like.. were in the trainings that I had. They were in my master's degree. When I had it, I didn't get my counseling master's degree until 2014, so a lot of it is still fresh in my mind. And honestly, it’s nothing to do with the box, but it really pained me when I moved here. And you guys still call us guidance counselors…. that really hurt. It's like we're not guidance anymore. We're school counselors. So it's….I know it's a generational thing and it’s having to teach people what it's about. But no, it's very good information. I really think it's applicable to teachers, what's in that box. It's kind of like the foundational skills that teachers need to know, even though they don't like being the counselor. But they're everything to those kids, you know. Participant 1 enjoyed the video and book, liked that video was specific and understandable; mentioned the other information was covered in their masters degree; noted frusteration that FL still considers them ‘guidance counselors; noted that box would be applicable to teachers who have critical relationships with students.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Absolutely. Yeah. Do you think that the box is more appropriate for teachers than it would be; for, like a social worker, mental health counselor, MFT, etc?

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: I think it would, if that social worker or school counter or BHP has that experience, but if they're brand new to it, I think it's good, and it's very helpful. I mean it just depends on how much experience they have, and what they're comfortable with, and what their mindset is of what a school counselor is, you know.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: I'm curious whether, like the level of information, maybe was like more like, even if the box is like cool and helpful and like gives like good reminders…Do you really think that the level of content is more appropriate for, like a teacher than a like a professional counselor or mental health person.

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: I do. I think it's more for teachers than it is for school counselors. That’s just my take.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, what about you, Evan? Did you learn anything you haven't learned before? Useful, not useful information, etc.

lines.speaker: Participant 2
lines.text: Well, like Kris I'm also from out of State…I’m from New York originally. I did my internships when I was in graduate school at a high school and a middle school. I also did substitute teaching in two different school districts up there as well. I think that my job as a school counselor has to do with collaboration with mental health counselors, school psychologists, school social workers…. teachers. It's really collaborating all around. I feel that although the stuff in the box maybe does pertain more to teachers than a school counselor, It's still very useful, because it's all like universal things that I have learned that have helped me do my job better. So I think that most of the stuff in the box is relevant to what I do and is helpful. But, like Kris said, it maybe leans more towards a teacher perspective than necessarily a school counselor.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Gotcha. And when you say teacher perspective, is it in the like way that the content is worded, or is it…like kind of like what Chris was saying more about like the level of like the maturity of the content, or whatever…. i'm trying to get the right wording.

lines.speaker: Participant 2
lines.text: It’s more, like content-wise, I think.  But, like I said, it's been very useful to me in general this year.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That's good for you two to just kind of going…this, I know, that this is kind of a future question: How could the box potentially be adapted to be a little more appropriate for school counselors or mental health professionals working in or with school settings? Or do you have, if you have any ideas? Not to put you on the spot.

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: That's a good question. I mean, I think I’d have to think about it, but I think it needs to go the next step, like maybe…I know we…we already know how to refer out to different agencies and psychologists and that kind of stuff. I'm just. I guess I need to think about it.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah. Well, if you think of anything kind of as we go through the questions, or if you just have just ideas, they don't have to be great ideas. They just need to be ideas, but just to.. feel free to throw them out there or throw them into your responses. Was there…just to kind of go back, was there any information in the box that you think is not useful at all, or that  really should be taking out or removed.

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: I thought it was important. I mean I don't…..I wouldn't take anything out because it's very well rounded. There's so many perspectives that….like the perspective and the grounding and the yoga and everything, there's just so many things that a student, if i'm going to use those with myself, like I said before, I use those techniques with my kids that I work with, that it gives kids choices. So I think it's… all of it was important.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Sounds good.

lines.speaker: Participant 2
lines.text: I agree with Kris. I wouldn't necessarily take anything out of the School counselor box. Like I said most of it is relevant. It just leans towards more of the teacher's side of things. I know we're not on question 3 yet, but I see “how the box impacts the way that you feel about vicarious trauma?”... “How did the box impact the way you feel about self care?” I actually just finished doing Suite 360 ‘self harming and suicide’ with my Seventh graders. And I guess the stuff in the box doesn't cover the entire scope of that particular topic. But it's such an important topic that I would like to see more information about what we can do to help students who are contemplating self harming themselves or suicide. Because that is a trauma that affects all populations at the High School, Middle School, hopefully not the elementary school level.. that young. But we do have kids that I have referred continuously to mental health counselors this year in my case load for all kinds of things, such as depression, anxiety, and mental health disorders that have not been fully diagnosed yet.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, that's good to know. And I think that that is a really useful tip, because I think a lot of people, sometimes even mental health professionals, don't know how to handle …like self- you know- injury….. absolutely.

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: I'm going to piggyback off of what he said as well, because we actually did Suite 360 last week as well. Wednesday through Friday we did sixth graders, Wednesday, seventh, graders….Thursday, and then eighth graders were on Friday. It was heavy. Like it's a lot, and the teachers don't like it, but it's required. And …but yeah, I agree with him that, having something for you know, when we had kids that have suicide risk assessments, and you know, threat assessments. Those kind of things are really huge because we're there, and we're on point when it's time to be. But when we come home, is it Aaron? Is that your name?

lines.speaker: Participant 2
lines.text: Even

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: Evan! Sorry, Evan… I don’t know about you, but when I go home I'm exhausted. I am mentally drained, physically, everything. Because you're putting on a show.. like you're there for the kids, you're talking about the lessons, and you're… I mean they're really into it, but it's like.. so much…it's just heavy. So I think, having something like he said, like Evan said, about having something in there, for that aspect would be helpful, too.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Sounds good. And just for my knowledge, I've heard of Suite 360. But for notes…what do you all do for Suite 360 at your schools?

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: Oh, well, it covers the requirements for Florida State …the department….for the State, what they want for mental health. One of them is sex exploitation, like human trafficking, suicide risk assessment. Suicide, talking about suicide and self harming, and then other things like bullying.  So there's different topics that we are required to show, and the State has approved of Suite 360. I'm not too keen on suite 360, but it was what they chose1.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Gotcha.

lines.speaker: Participant 2
lines.text: I agree with Chris. I thought it was an extremely important topic to talk about. As I was going to senior year of college, I went to college in Massachusetts. I went to UMass Amherst. My college roommate’s… really almost best friend committed suicide at age 21. And back then I don't think he was getting the adequate help that he needed, and didn't have the right people there for him when he went through that. And that whole experience changed him forever. From what I knew of him and my junior year and senior year. So I didn't know really what to do, because I had actually met him. He had come up to college a few times to visit him. So I myself needed someone to talk to about this kind of issue, and I was, you know, reaching out to people that lived on my floor, and you know, people I was friends with, and so forth.  I think that because I have a caseload of approximately 250 to 300 students. It's a very large middle school….Congress is approximately 14,-1,500 students…It's very hard to provide that individualized attention to everyone who needs it. So, you know, like Kris said, it could be a daunting task, and it could also be exhausting at the end of the day, but it's also, you know, it's challenging, but rewarding at the same time.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text:
Definitely. Yeah, thank you, guys for sharing that. I..like I said... I was familiar with that, but not super familiar. So thank you for educating me on that. 

For you all…Did the box have any other influence or impact on how you feel about vicarious trauma or self-care.

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: Hmm. Not that I can think of.

lines.speaker: Participant 2
lines.text: Yeah, I can't think of anything specifically.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Sounds good. And for you were there any kind of outcomes from using the box like, did you do anything different or like did anything happen or change after you use the box, for example?

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: Well, the post that notes are great, because I just stick them on my monitor, and they're a good reminder, and using them with my team…that's one thing you know, Evan had talked about. You know you have your team or you have…you know you go home, you're exhausted, or whatever. But that's what I love about middle school. Elementary….you, I, feel like you're the lone wolf. That used to be me at Lake Park Elementary up in Riviera Beach. And now that I'm at Polo Park, I love when you have a team that works well  together. So let's say you're working with a kid who is..you're going through a suicide risk assessment with. And you have your BHP alongside of you , you know, working with you. And then that other, the other school counselor that's not in the play…he or she is picking up the kids that you can't see, because you're in a suicide risk…. You know what I mean. So it's just having that collaboration happening. And then, when you say something, let's do this, and we do. what are called opening rituals for our counselor PLCs every week, and we use stuff like this. The grounding and perspective taking, and just taking a sip of coffee or tea, or whatever, and just enjoying the moment. I think, as adults. We forget to do that… and go go go, and we think we're robots, and we're not so. I do appreciate the post-it notes. Because they are a reminder, even though I see them all the time…they are a good reminder.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: It's good to know

lines.speaker: Participant 2
lines.text: Just the backbone what Kris just said. I'm a big fan of posting notes myself. If you were ever in my office at school, you would see that it keeps me extremely organized with the work that I do. I’m extremely detail oriented. So I.. you know I'm always writing things down and trying to keep track of everything I do. So like when I need to get to something or  I have to schedule a meeting or something like that,  I have it all in, you know, the generalized area… like on my computer monitor or somewhere on my desk, so that I could, you know, reach and you know, get it when I need it. So the post that notes are definitely a vital thing that were in the box to me.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Awesome. For you all.. have you had conversations about.. Or would you have had conversations about vicarious trauma or self care if you didn't have the box?

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: Yes, I would. You’re saying, would I talk about it without having that box in front of me.. Yes, absolutely. We are very good as a team. We have two… our BHP is a licensed therapist and then we have our co-located who is therapist from the outside agency on our campus. And it's just you learn that in your program, and I've always remembered that. And being a kid… I did not know what that was, because I went through a lot of trauma as a kid, and all the ACEs (adverse childhood experiences)  and all that. And it was just interesting to see when I took.. went through the program for my masters, that wow! You take on that load, and yes. So does that answer your question?

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah. And for you, where do you usually turn to get information on like vicarious trauma or self-care? Like you talked about your program. So do you like.. rely mostly on that masters education? Or are there other places you go for kind of resources, or support around vicarious trauma or self-care.

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: Well, I do that. And then I always go online and look. I can't remember what its called..NAMI? Is that right? The National Institute…. I go to them. And then there's a program that was created in Washington State that we used in our school district that I came from, and it's called Character Strong. Have you ever heard of it before?

lines.speaker: Morgen Cooley
lines.text: Not familiar.

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: It's a great SEL curriculum, and so we used it in our whole entire district. And it was amazing. I mean, you had screeners that were done on all the kids. The teachers did screeners, and they just inputted information so you could pick out who was.. what kids were high on the list that needed help, because they went through a lot of trauma. We did our ACE scoring and all. I mean, it was just amazing. So that's where I got my information, because it's all research based… So..

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, that's awesome.What about you, Evan? Do you normally have conversations with your colleagues or others about vicarious trauma or self-care?

lines.speaker: Participant 2
lines.text: I actually went through a mental health awareness training that was mandatory by my school back in February. I have a pretty close relationship with the mental health counselors that work in my school. There’s two of them.  So a bulk of what I learned about vicarious trauma and self care was through the huge manual that I have from the mental health awareness training that I went through. They had someone - I don't know if she was from the district… if she was from the school district of Palm Beach County, or if she was a third party that came to talk about this particular topic to us.  I gained a lot of my education about mental health in general from that training, as well as you know, about trauma and self care, and so forth.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Gotcha. And before that training, did you talk about it much…or? 20:008--> 00:20:49.620

lines.speaker: Participant 2
lines.text: : Not as much. And the woman who gave the presentation had said that there is a stigma attached to mental health, and a lot of people don't like to talk about their feelings, or, you know, on a day to day basis. And when I check on my students… I always ask.. you know, how's your day going? How are you feeling today? Sometimes, if I notice they're not their usual self, I'm like, are you feeling depressed? Are you sad today, or are you happy? What is it that you're doing today? How are your classes going? You know…basic…you know, conversation starters without, you know..getting too much information out of them, but by the same time keeping them, you know..active and just finding out how their day is going.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Sounds good. And for you all, if you've had these prior conversations… And so, now that you have this training, what are those conversations like? What do you talk about? How do you …like is it around support? Is it around resources? Is it around checking in just kind of giving some examples…

lines.speaker: Participant 2
lines.text: Well, I have a open-door policy. I rarely close the door to my office for various reasons, especially in the world that we're living in today. I would like all school faculty as well as the students to feel comfortable coming into me to talk about anything that's on their mind, you know, in any given day. And if there's any kind of problem that I can't resolve, I'll often refer them to a mental health counselor, school psychologist, or an administrator…. If you know the problem, I can't solve it on my own. But it's just the collaboration and teamwork in my school…. and this being my first year, seems to be pretty good all around. So that's basically the kind of knowledge that I offer to my students. They're not always comfortable coming to me because they don't know me. Like I said, I have a caseload of 253, and if it's something personal… I had one girl the other day say that she was good, and she didn't really want to talk about what was going on either in school or her home life, and those are two very separate things: school and home life, and sometimes I find a student could be very academic, but have not a good home life. Or vice versa, they have a very good home life, but they're not good in school, and they're, you know, academically failing. So I think all those things combined are really something that contributes to, you know, self awareness.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: definitely.

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: I…are you talking about Question Number 6?

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah. So what are like… kinda your prior conversations like. And then, if the the box has been helpful, in like kind of adjusting your changing the conversation at all.

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: The box really hasn't changed the conversation. After we have an incident with a student, or they've told me something that's happened with them at home that you know kind of prompts my brain like ‘oh, no’ or whatever…Then I talk that over with our BHP or another school counselor, if my BHP… It's always with another person, because I'll tell them what happened, and then they’ll ask me, how did you feel about that? Or did that prompt anything you know with what you're thinking, or was that too much for you, or too heavy? Because..or do you think any changes happened with this student as..after they responded that way to you. And are they going to trust you. Those kinds of things. And so it just helps me figure out…okay…did I ask the student the questions that I really wanted the answers to? Or was I being reactive? You know, because we always like get caught in it sometimes, and we're like, okay, hold the boat. Let's focus on what we need to focus on. So yeah, it's always nice to have somebody. At my other school, I didn't have that. So it was really heavy, having to go home and go…’Okay, did I do it right? Because SEL wasn’t important where I came from before, at the elementary. And it was like, you need to be on the wheel. Well, being on..you know what I mean by being on the wheel?

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: No, that was my next question…but I didn't want to interrupt you!

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: So being on the wheel in elementary means that you're on the fine arts wheel. So you're considered like music, PE, art. So you're just another time-filler for the teachers to have a break. And that was my placement, and that.. I said no. And they were like: You need to think outside the box.  I go: I can't think…I am thinking outside the box. I want my students to have mental health as being important as much as academic..and even more. So anyway. Yeah, it's just nice to be able to collaborate with people and just run things by them, and for them to say - you kind of went in a little bit deep. You need to back up a little bit and give that student time.  Like it was just nice to have that feedback.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah. So it sounds like for you.. I'm just kind of thinking of like the box like, if there were maybe a future iteration, like maybe questions or conversation topics, or like ways to connect people to their colleagues, or, like, you know, checking in with each other or something. Do you think that would be helpful? Just like having that social support? But having, like the box, maybe kind of prompt people to reach out for support?

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: I would do that. Just to… kind of as a reminder. I mean we… if we're in the environment that's conducive to having that collaboration happen, then great. But if we don't, then we need to be like reminded - you cannot do this on your own. Because I think school counselors have that mindset. You're doing everything. You're a superhero. And that's wrong. I used to believe that. I don't believe it anymore. We should not be

lines.speaker: Participant 2
lines.text: I agree with Kris. If I can interject here for a minute, collaboration is key in a school. Like I said before, you're working with administration, teachers, school psychologists, school social workers, mental health counselors. It's.. it's an all around battle. If you can't necessarily solve an issue yourself like…i'll go into the eighth grade guidance counselor, who is the director of guidance in my school…you know, and who's been an amazing mentor to me in my first year as a school counselor, and try and resolve the issue, and if not, i'll go to the ESOL Counselor: English Second Other Language, which we have two of in our school. Sometimes i'll get, you know… parents calling that speak another language or something. So I have to, you know, collaborate with them because they're Spanish speaking, or they speak…you know..Creole. . or another language. We have a very big Spanish and Creole speaking population in the school that I work in. So I think that those things are, you know, all pretty relevant, as far as like to the things that are in the box. But you know, I guess, addressing languages might be something we might throw into that school counselor box. What to do, you know, when…you know...talking with students and parents that don't necessarily speak English as a first language, and you need help resolving a problem but there's a language barrier or something like that.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, that's a good piece of advice. So I like that kind of… like.. reaching out, collaboration. But then also kind of resources for students whose first language is not English. Absolutely.  For you all, how relevant is the topic to the work that you do.

lines.speaker: Participant 1
lines.text: I mean it's relevant, I, you know… it comes up every day. Especially in middle school. I don't… I mean at Lake Park Elementary, where I was… it was all Haitian, and so we had a lot of trauma that was happening, and parents had a stigma about: If my kid needs help in anything, it's my fault as a parent, and I'm a bad parent, so they don't have a problem. So I think it's very relevant.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah.

lines.speaker: Participant 2
lines.text: I agree with Chris. I think you know it…it is [relevent]  to the topic, the work that we do. You're never going to be able to please everyone, and some parents can be almost as bad as the kids, if that even makes sense. And not wanting to really help a situation that is just becoming a constant conundrum, and just going back and forth. And you're like - well, I can't solve this because, the parent is not being cooperative. They won't even come to the school and meet with me so we can go over a students' grades…or find out…you know why they're so truan (truancy), why aren't they coming to school? Like I have kids in my caseload that like don't even come to school that have been absent for like 90 days. And we have to do home visits and so forth to find out..you know. And then some of them move. Like I had a kid in my caseload that moved three times this school year. How do you learn like that? He was at Eagles Landing in Boca. Then he came to Congress middle, and then he moved all the way into Broward County. And I was like… I hope I helped him to the best of my ability. But I don't know how you even learn with a teacher in a classroom when you're transferring schools three times in one year. So, maybe more information on those kind of topics, and how we can work together, you know, as a team to be more proactive in a student’s academic life at the school.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: I wonder.. like it's not, maybe so much the vicarious trauma, but almost kind of like the moral injury that can come when you might not have all the resources to do the job the way you know you need to do it. Is that kind of more what you’re describing?

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: I'm trying to figure... I think it's moral injury or moral hazard:  Like, when you know…your context or your resources are limited, and you just are doing the best you can. But when you are serving students who have like high levels of need, or if the students have trauma of course, and moving could definitely be traumatic for anybody, but especially for youth. For sure. Yeah. Was he moving for like reasons related to grades or family disruption, or anything like that?

You know, if you ever want to talk or anything, you know you can…. you can always call my office, or you know let me know how you're doing in your new school. And he was like, okay, I appreciate that.

Because half of my caseload is academically failing math and science in my school. And if they don't make up the work in critical thinking classes, then they can't move to the eighth grade. So I…. I suggested that to one of the APs in my school.  I said, you know how about student planners for these kids. You know, so we can get them more organized for their their, you know, homework, class work, assignments, test and quizzes. So that they know on a given day I can reach into my backpack boom. I have a student planner, and I can write everything that I need to know down, and I can be as organized as I can possibly be. So that might be something that could be thrown in there.

And the more time you spend being a school counselor, and you have those experiences, the better you get -  hopefully - at talking to parents and staff and admin..and also advocating for your role. Like that's one thing that really.. I don't know what it is about Florida, but a lot of the Florida School counselors don't like saying what a school counselor should and should not do. And a lot of principles say, well, our hands are tied. I'm like no, they're not..you're the principal. It's all school based, and there are certain things that you have to do. There's an email address in there, and then the parent doesn't respond either. Is that what you're saying?

And Mom and Dad will never know, because I'm gonna block the school's number on their cell phone. And believe it or not -  that's happened several times this year, and the AP had to get to the bottom of it.. and call and say , you know you have to come to school because we can't have your kid in school if he's going to continue to act out and cause...you know drama and problems for everyone else in school. Because I would say 80 to 90% of the fights are due to social media. That you know…maybe we could have some information in the box about..you know….how we can just try and combat that, if possible. I don't know if it is.. because social media is freedom of expression, and they can't provide censorship. But I think it would all be key things to possibly, you know, have information on.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text:
Yeah. So some of the things that you're talking about like might go in this box, or it'd be like other topics. She, I think, has been diagnosed with bipolar disorder. I didn't know it was possible to be diagnosed at 12-13 - that early on in life, with that disorder. And as I was coming back from lunch duty, she had another girl and a choke hold, and they were all running down the hallway, and then a fight ensued. And the kids instigate it,  it in my school, and it's just.. it's horrible. I'm like, they're here for an education, not to be fighting with each other. So yeah, I think it would be beneficial to maybe have a separate box with those kind of, you know, informational topics.

lines.text: I agree a 100%. I mean, I think that..and I totally believe… that social media is across all socioeconomic status, because a lot of our kids have phones and they are addicted to them. And of  course, having to be… here we go another-  maybe another box! Might be about parenting. But i'm not joking. But it's like they are asking me -  and Evan it might be the same with you -  but they're asking me - what do I do as a parent? I’m like: be the parent. You cannot be their friend. You need to tell them. No, you need to ground them or take away a privilege. It's a right to eat. They have a right to be clothed. They have a right to be.. have shelter.. but other than that, you need to take away things that they would like to have. That way it motivates them to listen to you, because otherwise they're going to be in control of what's going on. And then they're disrupting your life.

lines.text: Well, I was aware of compassion fatigue and secondary trauma, or what do you call it… like, you know. Because right now it's so academically based in my job; like everything being in high school trying to get these kids graduated and everything. So to really break it down and reconsider and slow down and say, okay, what else is going on? Why is this student not…let me take a look, talk to the student and figure out what is going on in their life currently that's blocking their path to graduation, so..

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That makes sense. 51

lines.speaker: Participant 5
lines.text: Yeah. I agree with her. Actually, I believe that all the information we kind of know what to do. But it's always good to have a refresher, and have a like.. an approach of how to do everything in little steps. So we can help not only students, but also, as the other friend.. colleague. was mentioning, other teachers. Because sometimes we forget that there are many things going on behind.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Absolutely thanks, Maria. For you all, was there any information in the box that wasn't as useful or helpful for you all? Like anything I guess you would take out from the materials?.

lines.speaker: Participant 5
lines.text: No, because I think self-care is.. like.. important to you. All the parts were important. It's important for me to leave all the parts. For me all of them were interesting.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Thanks, Maria. Anybody else, anything that you would take out?  I see a no from Kara.

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: No, but there were definitely things that I would not use at this moment. You know, it may be at a different time for a different outcome, or, you know, situation.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Was there like…was there one material that you're like…hmmm.. I don't know. Like not to take it out, but that you wouldn't use? Just out of curiosity…

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: The cards…right now. I forgot what they were.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Is it peer to peer cards?

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: Peer to peer…would that be used for the adults, or for the students?

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: I think it's for the adults. I'm looking. I have my list here somewhere.hold on.. of the stuff in the box. The peer to peer cards…they're kind of there to help recognize acute struggles or support, and they kind of build peer-to-peer support for…like kind of.. empathy and like understanding of.. kind of that initial..like.. first hand experience with vicarious trauma.

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: I probably wouldn't use that, in that I think that the teachers do not really have a lot of time. So I think more…it’s more important to just have a conversation that is just ..like.. natural, more natural, than for them to feel like I'm sitting them down and doing like a lesson with them. So yeah, I probably wouldn't use those

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Sounds good. So a different…you would probably….would there be a resource that you would want for how you would.. like kind of sit down and do those debriefing like… groups or moments?

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: Now that I just said that, I probably would use it when we have faculty meetings. I probably would take out one card now that i'm thinking about it. I'm trying to think of it in its totality how I would use it. So yeah, I guess I could use it during meetings, faculty meetings. And just talk to them about it, and you know, go from there. So it would be a good way to utilize it, now that I'm thinking about it.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That sounds good, that's helpful to know, because those are like instructions or things that we could potentially clarify in the box, so feel free to always add anything that we can do to make the user experience… kind of the box.. better or more clear. That's helpful.

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: Okay. You’re welcome.

lines.speaker: Participant 3
lines.text: Yeah, maybe more instruction with them. Because when I looked at them the first time, I wasn't really sure …like was I supposed to write on the back.. or have someone write on the back..like i'm here to support you, and like, you know, explain why.. how… or..I wasn't 100% sure what they were used for.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, that makes sense. Thanks Alyssa. Anybody else kind of want to add about…like ..the usefulness of information, or making it more useful? All right. How did the box impact the way that you feel about vicarious trauma or self care? I know some of you mentioned… like… it's always good to have reminders that you can take care of yourself, so I know that's one of them. But was there anything else that the box did in terms of like… influencing the way that you think about vicarious trauma or self care?

lines.speaker: Participant 6
lines.text: I think it was a good stop, and just do. And get ready to take care of yourself because we know - Oh, yeah, yeah, I know, I know. But this was like, oh, I need to make this a priority and make sure… and just do some self reflection. And I would say, too, that the quality of these materials is really impressive. Just, you know, putting it in my hands again, and touching it I'm like, wow, this…it's… It's very. very quality. Good job with that.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Thank you. Yeah they are meant to be used not just like a piece of paper that you print and like it's stuck under something else, and you forget it’s there.

lines.speaker: Participant 6
lines.text: I almost don't want to use them because they're too nice, if that makes sense.

lines.speaker: Participant 5
lines.text: Even the Box.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, yeah, I've heard that before. I don't have one of those boxes myself, but I've heard that, too. I see your thumbs up, Kinetra.  For you all…were there any other outcomes of…. and feel free to kind of jump back to the impact of using the box. ..but we'll kind of combine these…but were there any different like… Did you do anything differently after using the box? Like in terms of how you talk about it, how you think about self care?  But we'll just combine those 2 questions…Or vicarious trauma.

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: I guess I used it to bring up the conversation again to the BHP. And I will make sure that I incorporate it with our mental health team, the psychologists and everyone else, because it's important, and it's important to recognize it. A lot of the things that were stated…I do them unconsciously, anyway. Like I tried not to watch a lot of news first thing in the morning, Only when it's necessary. I try to have something on that’s really funny in the morning, so I can get my day poppin’, you know. So a lot of the things I do unconsciously. But I want to make sure that the people who are around me and on my team… they're doing it as well.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Awesome. Yeah, I like that idea. I think I need to.. like.. do that as well. So.. I can emphasize within the social field…sometimes.. thanks Kanitra.. Anybody else, any kind of like… Did you do anything different? Think anything different after using the box? All right, so oh, sorry Maria! Where are you going to jump in?

lines.speaker: Participant 5
lines.text: No, no. I wasn’t

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Sounds good. So the next question for you all is, would you have had conversations about vicarious trauma or self-care and kind of like within the context of your job if you didn't have the box. Is that kind of a regular topic for you?

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: Sorry to keep talking, everyone.

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: I had something with the district that is called ‘Prepare’ and that was the first time that I actually learned about vicarious trauma. So I came back, and I was just talking [about] my mental health to anybody who would listen. I was so impressed that ….you know. And so I've heard it before, and I would just try to keep it alive and continue to address it year after year, because it's so relevant to our job.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: What about the rest of you? Have you talked about vicarious trauma or self-care kind of within the context of your work before?

lines.speaker: Participant 6
lines.text: I think I've done it mostly with my team as we have conversations, or we start talking about frustrations with…you know… our our school administration or campus…what's going on. Just having personal… kind of.. relationships with the different people that are on my team. But I feel like that would be who I am, anyway. And I don't know if this made me think of it more, or if it was just more validating of - oh, yeah, this is important to maybe continue to do that- maybe reach my circle a little bigger, not just my immediate team, but try to reach out to the the teachers, who, I know you can tell that are in a funk and have, you know, an attitude that's very difficult to deal with.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, yeah, absolutely. Alyssa or Maria…Do you want to add to that? Or would you have these conversations outside of the box.

lines.speaker: Participant 3
lines.text: I didn't always, I guess. Now that I was thinking about it. But this year has been a rough year for me personally, so a lot of my perspective has changed. And I just got an email yesterday from a teacher that you know, seemed really broken. So I'm trying my best to like, really support her, even though I don't know her that well. This is only my second year at the school. But you know I don't like seeing my teachers suffering and having to deal with certain things as well. So I'm trying to be as supportive as I can for her, so that way she can be there for her students, and just kind of finish out the rest of the year. So I think, since… you know the beginning of… since January, since I had my own little trauma go on, having this box has kind of been helpful. Because, even as it says, like, put on some music. I'm like all right. I'm putting on my Pandora, and I'm listening to my Phil Collins. Just you know, to kind of keep myself in my own head space and that way when a kid walks in…. I'm always in a good mood, because I have my music playing, and you know I could be there for them.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That's good. Thank you for sharing that

lines.speaker: Participant 5
lines.text: It also helped me. Well, I mean this is something that I always have done. But since I’ve had the box, it helped me to shown even more how I care about other teachers. And try to share with them, as I would say like this is, you know… that sometimes it's important that we prioritize our mental health, and make sure that we are happy. So I am. ..I have been trying to care more about everyone -  how their families are doing, how our day [ is going], and try to encourage them to take a little bit of time and try to accomplish one goal every day in regards to their personal life…or something that they want to accomplish. And then just do the things that they have to do at school. So the box has helped me a little bit more to work or get a closer approach to other teachers, and to reinforce [to] them that they do transmit to children and they need to be happy. We need to also look after ourselves.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah.  It sounds a little bit like there's a theme of that you are in some ways like a a team leader and kind of supporting the teachers and kind of connecting with other BHP’s or other mental health staff that you have on on your teams, and that maybe the box was kind of helpful for just kinda like being able to bring those tools to other people and continue to support your teams.

lines.speaker: Participant 5
lines.text: Yes, exactly. I’m a school counselor so I’m trying to just give support not only to students but also to teachers and people around the school, administration, cleaners, staff members, everyone.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Thanks, Maria. So I'm going to kind of combine the next couple of questions because they kind of relate to this one. I've heard a little bit, I think, from conversations that your prior discussion of vicarious trauma or self-care, often comes from venting frustrations or trying to support teachers, for example. But it sounds like the work is relevant to what you do. Have you had other types of conversations besides, you know, kind of like informal venting like not in a judgmental way at all..but like informal conversations around, like debriefing or kind of just venting frustrations after a hard day around this topic? Or is there anything else about this topic that's especially relevant to what you do?  I think we're kind of covering it. I just want to make sure I open the space up.

lines.speaker: Participant 5
lines.text: Well, I think in the part [about] dealing with trauma…transmitting to others the information that we've got from the box. And try to explain what are some of the steps and advice that we can give to other children? It's something that I have found in the box. And [something] we can give to others.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Sounds good. Yeah, I think when you're working in such big teams and one person's feeling a little off, you know you can always assume you know what it is, but it can also influence the way your team is working if you don't address it. So I think all the things you're saying are very relevant, you know. I laugh just because I had a recent situation where one person on the team was having a rough day, so I can empathize with that, you know. But the box helps to remind us we can support each other when they're having bad days, too. Yeah, definitely. So the next question is back to the materials: what do you think were the most helpful materials compared to the less helpful materials for the box. And we'll kind of just go into a conversation around like your recommendations or suggestions for enhancing the box, or if you would add anything to the box. Feel free to kind of throw anything out there that is relevant.

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: My most helpful part of the box was the video because I could work while I listen.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: So, having materials that you can use during a busy day or during a busy time could be helpful.

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: We're always multi-tasking. Our job is pretty heavy

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: I know I was talking to a group last night, and they're like -  I think every day I’m just exhausted, so I send all the care back your way. And then anybody else? I know Maria has to jump off a little bit early. But does anybody else have anything most helpful or less helpful?

lines.speaker: Participant 6

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: No problem. So we're on question number eight There you go. Question eight.

lines.speaker: Participant 6

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Kind of further application of how you can use it like on the job it sounds like too.

That was probably like my favorite: trying to kind of guess what the pictures were, and then reading about them, and stuff like that. I do apologize. I have to go to lunch detention, So I'm going to be a little…I might lose you for a minute and then I’ll try and jump back on. But, duty calls.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: No problem! I totally understand, no worries at all. So I think we're actually on question 9…outside of vicarious trauma and self care, are there other topics that you'd like to see covered in a box, or any other types of resources that you would want from like LSIS or other places to support your work.

lines.speaker: Participant 6
lines.text: Yeah. So I think I I mentioned earlier, just having a resource place where..you know… and we have this with our school counselor program planner…but maybe just a resource where:  ‘Okay, this is. This is what you can do with a student, you know, with anxiety, depression, or you know someone is, you know, suffering with grief... Just a a go-to place where everything is in one spot would be nice to not have to keep….’okay, that's on this part of the website of our mental health care section for the school district, or this is over here, and that's over there.’ It would be really giving it to us in a one stop shop of all of the things… most of the things that we work with. Whether it's, you know the suicide prevention, or the substance abuse, that you have a great course on that as well. But you know something like that would be great to have all of it in one place. That may be asking a lot.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Well, I don't know. I say, ask away, because you never know. I don't know if you know Dr. Spencer, but she is full of energy, and always up to the challange. So she would love to hear the feedback. I know she'll be excited to hear, you know the summary for sure. But yeah. So it sounds like kind of a resource warehouse or something that's just a little easier to navigate. But then you also mentioned other topics like mental health. I know last night somebody mentioned on suicidal self injury was like a big thing like outside of suicide, because it's related, but you know, not the same. And it's like a big thing that they were dealing with at their school. Any other kind of topics or things that would be helpful besides resource libraries, or specific topics?

lines.speaker: Participant 3
lines.text: I would like, maybe, some positive affirmations, things that I could give to my colleagues and things I could give to my students and things that I can remind myself of as well.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah. So kind of like school related, or would you have other topics in terms of positive affirmations?

lines.speaker: Participant 3
lines.text: I mean I definitely would use school related…but as well as like off campus type of stuff, maybe very general, even. But even general like “you've got this, you can do this”

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Sounds good. So positive affirmations, global and specific to the school environment. Anything else that you can think of that you would like to hear from the box, or see from the box. I know, and somebody else mentioned it… their other boxes that they do are substance use prevention for families like mostly middle school [and] high school age. They have a mental health box that's more specific to anxiety for school children. They have a medication literacy box for elementary age children, kind of teaching them about medicines and medicine safety, but specific, like puppets - and things that are catered towards kind of a developmental level of an elementary school child. But I know that they're looking for other ways to expand.

lines.speaker: Participant 6
lines.text: Like a health resource as far as a general wellness.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Like a physical health..? Can you give me some examples just so I can make sure I can…

lines.speaker: Participant 6
lines.text: Well because right now I partner with our health and wellness teacher to combine a lot of the guidance topics, and we do cover, you know…medicines, and that's along with the substance of use prevention. We also talk about nutrition and sleep and hydration. All of those things as far as the the physical health, and then I tie in the mental health side of it with it, and we just kind of merge our content areas. To just make the fine arts course being: ‘wellness’ that every student gets throughout the year. So I mean all of that sounds great. Like I want the mental health box. I want that. I want all those boxes now. But that's why I'm trying to just collect resources. I just want to get all the information, but not be overwhelmed by… “okay, this isn't really a great resource.” You know I'd rather have someone vet them out and say, “this is a really good…” I meant not approved, because I mean there's the whole library, banned books thing… I don't want to go there. But something that's just quality that's relevant. That's going to help us right now. Not that you know…ancient.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: So it's kind of like evidence-supported resources that you know are high quality that you can go to, and you don't have to like… do your own [research]. You don't want to have to do the research when you're already in the midst of a busy day. Just pull it out and go.

lines.speaker: Participant 6
lines.text: Right!

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: That's my question. My follow up question to that is…are these vetted? With these materials, will we have to go through [an LSIS] person or whomever to actually use them? If there were materials provided…..with the law that has come into play.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah. So I'm pretty sure that anything that LSIS gives out has to be vetted first. But that's a really good question that I’m not going to answer definitively without knowing. So I'm actually gonna write that down as soon as we finish today. So I can ask Dr. Spencer. I think that what is in the box is approved by Palm Beach, or their Palm Beach resources. So I think what you have in the Resource Library is good to go, and that might be the hard part about some of the resource library. I think, that they might have been limited to what's approved Just there's been a lot of changes within State policy recently, so I think anything in there is vetted and approved at this moment. But let me double check that for you. So that's a very, very good question, and a very real question right now. I laugh because on Higher ED we're dealing with similar challenges with higher ED stuff. So I get that. Anything else that you guys.. anything you wanted to be asked that you weren't asked? Or anything you wanted to add that just kind of popped into your brain before we say goodbye today?

lines.speaker: Participant 6
lines.text: I had a question. Are you looking from this feedback to send out another wave of these boxes with some changes? What is the next step that you're wanting to take with LSIS?

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: So I know for these boxes they have a round that's already printed that's going to specifically go to teachers and school staff …like non-Counselor school staff. But I know that whenever there's a pause, and the ability to kind of wait for the next funding, application to come out..they'll go back and update the material. So that's why it's helpful to know likey ‘hey’, Like having some sort of roadmap or instructions, having, you know, maybe more resources that we know are vetted and approved. Making sure that, like maybe there's a note in the box that says, hey, these resources are approved to use with your kids, or these are ones just for you or something like that. I'm pretty sure that anything in the box would have to be vetted. But I don't know, but that would be really good to make note of so that you know for sure that you can use them right away. So those are all like things that I think would come out after the next funding round. But we will take any and all suggestions, because the boxes are not not for them, you know they're really for you all.

lines.speaker: Participant 6
lines.text: Oh, and I think you made a point making this a combined kind of effort with SLL (skills for learning and life)  would be a good partnership, because there's so many topics that are very complementary that you could… at least even for the classroom teachers who are doing morning meeting and are using the SLL explicit lessons. I think this would be a good [idea]. I could see, having those positive affirmations, and those sticky notes being a great additional material to give out to the students to kind of..[as a] take away, or something that they stick on their desk because we can read it every day, or you know something to that nature.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah. absolutely. It's a great idea.

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: So I know that the boxes are really intended for us right, and the staff to try and help us understand the burnout and what we experience. But I know that we're moving more …because that's who we are… we're moving more to how we could still help the kids with everything that's going on. But I wanted to know with that mental health box…how would I access that? If I already have the one that Dr. Spencer gave out for the family ….like munch and eat, or talk while you eat, or something… but that's a personal one. It's not to be used with the kids here. But is the mental health box for the kids…for us…or who’s the audience?

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: I think the mental health box is more for the youth and the family, the youth and parents, your kids and parents. But like that's it… if you're saying like - hey I think that actually might be a great tool to have like a ..you know, a box that I could take into a classroom if a teacher's having a rough class day, because you have a couple of students who are dealing with this today, or something like that. You know... So if you have suggestions for that, feel free to throw that out. But it sounds like, maybe like a mental health for school counselors, or like something that’s specific to like a classroom environment is that what I’m hearing?

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: Yes, or specific to different audiences. Like, okay, we may have one that's specific  to the staff that we do at Staff meetings. We may have one that's specific to the students. Of course we know we have to get it vetted and make sure we're inside the law. And then we may have one…. I'm trying to think of another audience…. I think that would be it. The staff, the kids.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, absolutely. You guys are not the only ones. I know a lot of people are saying that the teachers are having a lot of burnout and other schools are saying teacher burnout is really high right now.

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: They’re struggling.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Because of stuff going on in the new stuff going on locally, stuff going on in politics and all of that.

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: Their households, I mean..you know we're dealing with things... we're still dealing with things post Covid. All the deaths that our kids and faculty and experienced. And we even experienced losing a faculty member.. two of them actually. So it's just a lot.. it's compounded. And that's what the book really validated. It’s that it's not just one thing. It's multiple things. So..

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Thanks for providing that perspective, I think that's a really great idea. I don't know how fast they'll come out, but I know she'll listen. ..she always listens so..

lines.speaker: Participant 4
lines.text: And it's always about the money you have to have funding.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, that's kind of why we partnered, you know it's why she came to FAU to say, like, hey, can you help us increase the quality of our evaluations? You might not be writing our grants. But can you help us do these objective things? So yeah, absolutely. Thanks Kinitra Alyssa. Did I see you take your mic off?

lines.speaker: Participant 3
lines.text: Yeah, I was just gonna say, I think you know I was using the box for me, but also kind of providing it to the students, or I mean, I'm sorry ..the teachers. So you know it would be nice to just focus on myself. But with all the burnout and stuff I do want to support my teachers as well, my colleagues so..

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Absolutely. Well, thank you all so much. That is it for today. If there is anything else that comes up, I forgot to put my email in the chat …feel free if you need anything, or if you need resources from social work at FAU. You can also Google Morgan Cooley. I'll just spell my name in case it helps to see it. And FAU… just if you need anything from us…we're mostly social work, but if you ever need support presentations, referrals… I might not be the right one.. I moved here right before the pandemic and then lost some contacts and was teaching only online and things. But I'm working on getting back out in the community a little bit more. But if you guys need anything, please let me know. But I look forward to sharing the summary of this with LSIS, and seeing what comes next.Thank you for what you guys do!

lines.speaker: Participant 3
lines.text: Thank you so much for your time. 219

lines.speaker: Participant 6
lines.text: Have a blessed day, everyone. Bye.

lines.speaker: Participant 3
lines.text: You too. Bye, bye. Thurs 4/6 at 5pm Group WEBVTT

lines.text: Sounds good. Yeah that's great. I've heard that from at least one other person to have just like some suggestions or instructions might be helpful.
