lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That sounds good. No, I really appreciate that. The box is not mine. I'm just here to share information and pass it along. But I will definitely pass that information along… that's really great feedback.

lines.speaker: Participant 8
lines.text: Yeah, I'm [similar], I went through the box and watched the video down on the screen. But I was kind of confused also about, there is no directions on what to do. I only do the cards and use the stickies as talking points. But you know, I was looking for more directions.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That makes sense. For you, did you say that you did try to use some of the stickies, or that you had not used the material?

lines.speaker: Participant 8
lines.text: No I read through them, and I looked at the videos. But other than that there was no stickies. I mean I was reading through all the stickies. And so I was wondering how to use it with the students. Like, if I'm doing counseling, or whatever…are those talking points…? I wasn’t sure.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That makes sense. I think that the stickies are meant just to be kind of like notes of encouragement, and you can use them how you want. But that is great feedback, and I will pass that along, because, if it's not clear…it's not clear! So I appreciate that. Somebody else has joined the waiting room. If you wouldn't mind just pausing really quickly, so I can let them in and check in with them. Thank you so much. Hold on just a moment. I'll come back to you all in just a second, and ask you your perceptions of the video. but I'll come back to Deborah in just a second after I check in with Louisa…here she gets signed in. Hi, Louisa! How are you? It's nice to meet you. We just got started, but I just wanted to check in really quickly. Are you okay if we record this focus group if there's no identifying information like brought up in the group. And would you be okay if we used any sample quotes from you if we never attached your name or identity to them.

lines.speaker: Participant 9
lines.text: Yes

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Sounds good. Basically this brief consent statement is just that this is a program evaluation for the box, and you don't have to answer or respond to anything you don't want to, and there's no direct risk or benefit. But yeah, but hopefully, we use the information to make improvements.

lines.speaker: Participant 10
lines.text: I played the video. And then I was trying to figure out….again this is how my brain works…. I was trying to figure out….how do I power it back up what it loses power. And because again I don't know… I'm not very techy. So I would have like preferred more directions in terms of how to utilize this box to the fullest..So that I can get the best benefit out of this box in working with my students. But I did like the video. and I saw the stickies - wasn't quite sure what to do with the stickies. But yeah I did like the box. I did like the concept. I like the video. Yeah, so that’s where I am right now.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Thanks, Deborah. So it sounds like both of you appreciate kind of the aesthetic or kind of the presentation of the box, but that all of you agree that just having some sort of like roadmap or instructions or suggestions for using the materials would have been helpful.

lines.speaker: Participant 10
lines.text: Yes, for me it would have been.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, I know talking to other focus groups… I think most people put the stickies on their computers or put them on teachers like, you know, if they have like a teacher friend or something like that, just kind of leaving encouragement.  But everybody's used them in different ways. But having any kind of suggestion on that, I like that idea. That's a great idea. Luisa…we're talking about what your experience was using the School Counselor Care and Support box. Kind of just your initial reactions or anything surprising about the box.

lines.speaker: Participant 9
lines.text: The first surprising thing ..in a positive way… is  that this is a box for me. It's not a box for me to help someone else. In all seriousness, that's all I do the whole day. Every day I have a master's degree in helping other people. Everything you give me. I'm going to try to implement in my practice. But the fact that this is for me it's like a dream come true. I don't want to explore this too much, but it's just like oh, my gosh! Someone knows that there is secondary trauma in school counseling. And there is a book about it! And it’s really cool  because I sometimes joke that people think school counselors are seeing kids, and chit chatting with kids the whole day and watching cute cat videos. That's what people must think.  And yet i'm like this: this week I did 2 suicide risk assessments with 2 kids. Like this is...we do disheartening things. So it was very…. how can I say? It gave me hope. The box gave something for me. And I like these stickies, because that's what I thought I'm doing.. whenever . Not just for me…. that's something that I can share with others. That is easy to share. And it brings me joy. So I really like the concept. And I thought the video explained it very well. Although I watched it the day that we received the box, and that was back in February. But I remember the feeling of watching the video saying. Okay, I know why this is created. I do think we could have suggestions on how to use some of it. Because not everything I’m going to be able to come up with a fabulous idea [of how to use it] and suggestions are appreciated. But I liked watching the video. And I’m a person who usually skips videos! So I appreciate it.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That's good. So it sounds [like] for you…You were surprised that it was just for you. But then you also like the materials, and could have appreciated maybe, some instructions for how to use the materials too.

lines.speaker: Participant 9
lines.text: There are instructions, but I mean suggestions on…like more than one idea on how to use it.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That makes sense. Yeah, thanks, Louisa. For you all, and I know some of you said that you like the video…did you learn anything from the box that you didn't know before? And did you find some information more helpful than others? Whether it was like the video or the book. How do you feel, I guess, about the content that was in the box. And feel free to just jump in.

lines.speaker: Participant 10
lines.text:
I don't remember any specifics but the content I really did like as I was playing it. I also had kids coming in and out of the offices. I'm trying to listen as well. But a lot of the stuff that they talk about….I knew. But for me it was a reminder.. because, even though you know things ..just having that reminder, having somebody to say it out loud. Because, even though we may have it in the back of our mind, sometimes we forget. And even just thinking about taking care of myself…. I was thinking of….I have a colleague…of having her to come and listen to the video as well. Because we talk about this all the time. You know.. the trauma that social workers and counselors and other helping individuals have. That we tend to be less [aware of]. We tend to forget that we need to be recharged as well. We need to be supported And as I was listening to the video, all I could think about is that I wanted to share this with some of my colleagues who are struggling particularly right now with things that's happening within the school system.

And that was really clear… I just came from a conference the Social Workers of America. And that [the] topic.. the trauma of burnout, of feeling like there is no support. So yeah, the video…even though much of the material wasn’t new, it brought it back for me. And I needed to hear that, again and again and again.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, definitely. I appreciate that. So it sounds like for you tt wasn't so much that the video was new, but it was refreshing, and it was refresher information that you kind of need to hear again and again.

lines.speaker: Participant 10
lines.text: Yes, absolutely because we forget. We don't think about it. You know you do your job, and it's just like walking. You know that you have to walk, but you forget that there are steps in this walking. And to do it correctly.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah. I know that it was mentioned in a couple of other groups that policy changes have had kind of a challenging impact on you all, or on school counselors and school staff and teachers and things. And may I ask, is it related to policy changes, or is it other things that are going on within the school? Or is it kind of like national news, kind of like violence and gun violence, and those kind of things? Or is it all of those things? But I'm just kind of curious for you all…what are some of those big challenges that are creating the burnout for you?

lines.speaker: Participant 9
lines.text: For me it's the state of Florida legislation. It's just every day I find something new. Yesterday I found out that there is a House bill….House Bill (HB) 1069 - that was approved, I think, the day before yesterday in the Florida Congress, and it's going to the Florida Senate and then it's gonna go to the Governor for his veto or not - that is, about no one in school until high School….something related to gender identity and supporting students. And at the same time.. the same day ..that I found that out, I'm having to deal with the suicide risk assessment of a student because of gender identity. So if this bill had already been approved…I would have to say, ‘student, I can’t’ I'm not counseling this student on that issue. But I wouldn't even be able to have that student there, because the bill is restraining a lot of things that we can talk about in the school setting. So for me it's the state of Florida that is to play, maintaining a lot of new laws and what we can have in our libraries for students and whatnot. That causes stress - having to scan 600 books in the library, otherwise you can't use them. It’s tough

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Thank you for sharing that, Louis. I just wanted to make sure. But that completely makes sense. It sounds very stressful. Deborah, are you having similar challenges?

lines.speaker: Participant 10
lines.text: Yeah, it's….you know, the different policies. Because you don't know from day to day, because depending on which way the wind is blowing - policies change! And they don't always tell you until the last minute. So there's always this fear, at least for me, that I’m gonna miss something. This something is gonna happen. And I'm gonna be held accountable for it. So it’s those kinds of things. In addition to some of the stress that families and children are facing and some of the emotional baggage the kids are bringing. That's pretty scary. Every day I go to work, it’s a fear. Because I don't know what's gonna happen. And I don't know always how to prepare for it. Because you can't be everywhere, every day, every minute of the day. WE have an expectation that you are supposed to be everywhere, and there's only one of you and many of our children and families.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, thanks Debra. So Samina or Lorraine…are you having some similar challenges, or seeing the same kind of trends in your schools?

lines.speaker: Participant 7
lines.text: Yes, it’s too many things, and they are not really giving us A to Z training about something. Just fill out this form. Fill out this form. Fill out this form.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: So it sounds like you're responsible for all the paperwork, in all these changes. But there, you don't really have control over what's going on. Is that what you mean? 118

lines.speaker: Participant 7
lines.text: I would say the instruction for us during training is not in order. If they will sit down and tell us, give us a solid example - an example that we actually deal with. And tell us, okay, at what point [you will] use this form. It's just haphazard. Everything is haphazard

lines.speaker: Participant 8
lines.text: And it's so much going on now with mental health. We’re overwhelmed with all the information and all the training that we have.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, just curious, is some of it related to Covid? Or is it most of it related to the policy changes or just kind of legislative issues?

lines.speaker: Participant 7
lines.text: Well, after the Marjory Stoneman act, all these trainings about suicide…suicide…suicide, and violence. But I feel like little bits and pieces are being thrown at us. Not one whole set of instructions. It’s confusing. My mind is confused about it.

lines.speaker: Participant 9
lines.text: You asked if it’s related to covid and at first I thought ‘no, no it’s not covid. Covid is not something going on right now. I mean it’s going on, but not like the past three years. This is the first year that I’m not thinking about covid…but then I stopped and thought, oh wait, it is about covid. Because the whole situation with Covid, in my opinion, caused a higher need for mental health services. I never had so many parents requesting support and school counseling for their kids like I had this year. This is just…oh my gosh. Not even during the two initial years of the pandemic, it wasn’t like this. Now I think we’re seeing the backlash from the pandemic in regards to mental health. Because the need for mental health services has increased. And the number of professionals hasn’t increased. So now we are having to service more kids and that increases the vicarious trauma! It’s all Covid but it’s not.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, that makes thanks for sharing that. I know that was a little off topic. But just to kind of understand the context for the vicarious trauma, and the demands that you're facing. I really appreciate that. Did anybody else want to add anything before I keep moving through the questions? Sounds good. So I know we were talking about what information was in the box and the content. What information was most useful and least useful; if you had to pinpoint or bullet a couple of items for each?

lines.speaker: Participant 7
lines.text: I think sticky notes

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Kind of like the positive affirmations?

lines.speaker: Participant 7
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: Participant 9
lines.text:
Affirmations are now in fashion. I  notice it's a thing now. It's everywhere. Everybody is talking about it. People are doing affirmation tattoos, affirmation mindfulness kind of thing, affirmation yoga… And it’s not something new, it’s just being marketed. And that’s a good things because more people are going to use it. So I think the post its are very easy if you want to share something positive and quick with co-workers, and that helps us because it helps create a better work environment. It’s all connected. And I really like the book because I love reading. So that’s very subjective for me. The book was very good and I like the post its. But everything there is very useful. 

The only thing that I just couldn’t figure out yet were the post cards.

lines.speaker: Participant 8
lines.text: She’s talking about the peer to peer cards.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Okay, the peer-to-peer are there to kind of help you during an immediate need for support or intervention. And so I think it's mostly meant to kind of start developing understanding and sympathy when you're talking to other professionals or staff.  I know some people have said they used them with students, you are not the only one who has said that they were kind of uncertain how to use them. I know one person talked about taking them and using them maybe in a staff meeting. If they were talking about a challenge or an occurrence or an event that happened or something like that. But it sounds like the peer-to-peer cards for you needed a little more clarity or instruction?

lines.speaker: Participant 9
lines.text: : Yeah, cause of course, I can come up with a way of using them. It's just that if I had suggestions about why they are there that would have helped me. Instead of having to think ‘how could I use it, how could I use it?’ I can always [think about] ‘how can I use it in different ways.’ I just need one [thing]: what is the intention when this was put in the box

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That makes sense. Did anybody else feel that way about the peer to peer cards or any of the other materials. That maybe these were a little bit less helpful for you?

lines.speaker: Participant 10
lines.text: That's what I was thinking, particularly with the peer-to-peer cards. If there could have been some suggestions or examples as to how to utilize the cards in the most effective manner. That would have been helpful. Sometimes just listening to other people giving an example will just kind of open up that brain power to go ‘ok!’ and then you could even enhance that. So just more examples as to how it could be utilized so that we know that we are doing something correct and using it in the most effective manner. But you were asking what was the most useful. To me, it was the video. Because I am a very [hands on learner]. I like to listen and hear and absorb what I’m hearing. And even though the material isn’t new, it allowed me to think and process some things with myself. So for me that was the most helpful because I love to process what’s going on with me. And think about things, and then come back at it, and think: now I have a better understanding as to what’s going on with me. And how I reacted to whatever it was.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah so the video taught you things you already knew. But it was what you needed to hear to kind of continue to process

lines.speaker: Participant 10
lines.text: Yes. Reawakened something inside of me.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Thank you Deborah. Does anybody else want to address what information was most helpful or least helpful? Which materials.

lines.speaker: Participant 8
lines.text: I enjoyed the videos. I really enjoyed the videos because even though we’ve learned the majority of it over our careers it gave a reminder, just like a refresher.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Sounds good. Thanks, Lorraine. For you all, did the box have any influence on how you feel about vicarious trauma or self care?

lines.speaker: Participant 10
lines.text: You know you're talking about vicarious trauma. It’s that as a health professional, I think for me it’s very hard for me to admit sometimes that I’m suffering. That I’m having a reaction. Because I’m so busy taking care of other people. This box for me helped me to at least acknowledge it and say it outloud. That’s why I said to you [that] listening to the video, without having to talk, just listening and processing that [was helpful]. Because as professional, sometimes you just don’t want to stop, think about what’s going on around you and how that is impacting you as a person, as a professional. Because we really don’t want to have to deal with that because we have so many other things to deal with. To deal with all these other things…and still take care of me in the best way that I need to take care of me. So for me, that’s what I got out of it as well.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Thanks Deborah. Does anybody else want to jump in or piggyback? Did the box have any other influence in how you think about vicarious trauma or self care?

lines.speaker: Participant 10
lines.text: I’m going to hop in again. Self care. And I know for professionals self care is sometimes the last thing that we do for ourselves. It really is. Because we don’t think that we have time to take care of ourselves because we have to take care of our clients. We have to make sure that our clients are doing okay and are healthy and are safe. And so sometimes self care is put on the backburner until something really happens. And then, we have no choice except to do self care.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, yeah. And I’m a social worker..so that NASW Code of ethics just added self care in somewhat recently. Like in the last year or 2. But it wasn't in our code of ethics, yet it influences the way we treat clients, and people and all of those things. So I think that's super relevant. Samina I just saw you unmute your mic, do you want to jump in?

lines.speaker: Participant 7
lines.text: I didn't catch the question. But I'm sorry! I'm listening to you guys, and I’m feeling so strange because I never applied it to us. I looked at the box - how to work with students. Now I'm paying attention to vicarious trauma. I didn’t pay attention to those terms. I just looked at the box and you know “trauma” and “counselors”..so. Now I see…okay. That helps a lot! Now I understand the box more!

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That makes sense. Maybe it would help if there was just a little bit of [extra clarification. Yeah. Well, hopefully, you'll use it, and you can let us know how it goes. But yeah. Thanks Samina! So we'll go ahead and keep moving, and if you want to come back to this, we can. But I'm curious ... .I'm gonna ask one of the probing questions for the next one. But have you done anything different in your work or your personal life since you used the box. Like have you engaged in more self care, or thought about it more, or talked to a colleague, or anything like that?

lines.speaker: Participant 9
lines.text: :I have made more of an effort in terms of engaging in self care. I wasn’t necessarily successful, but at least! No sometimes I was successful! And that was thanks to the box! But it’s more in my mind. Like reading about it. Studying vicarious trauma [while] of course I know what it is, the fact that I received a box, as a school counselor, with a book there and that’s the purpose. I’m like okay. This is a thing. I need to do something about it. And its’ not just me.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah definitely, thanks Louisa. Anybody else?

lines.speaker: Participant 10
lines.text: For me it’s a work in progress. I'm not there yet, but it's work. And I think about it. And it’s a work in progress and I have to mentally make myself do certain things. And I think for me, I haven’t done it recently, but I need to go back and listen to the video again. I think it’s just a timely reminder for me to take care of me so that I can give the best care to my students and families.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah that’s very true. I teach college students. And I often think what would I want them to do if they were feeling like I’m feeling. And sometimes it’s hard like you mentioned before. It’s hard to take care of yourself when you are trying to take care of other people or help other people first. But yeah I think that’s great. Thanks Deborah, Lorraine or Samina I know that you guys had some different experiences but have you dont anything different since using the box?

lines.speaker: Participant 7
lines.text: Honestly My perspective was entirely different, so I have not applied Box to myself. No.

lines.speaker: Participant 8
lines.text: No, I havn’t been applied to myself but I’m planning to. I’m glad we had this focus group -  now I'm more aware. So I will be using it. And I was looking through the book Healing Secondary Trauma. I think I will give it a read and go from there. But I’m glad we had this group so thank you!

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Well, thank you guys, I know it's 5 o'clock on the Thursday before a holiday weekend. So I really appreciate that. The next question for you, is.. I know a couple of you have mentioned that you have had conversations or you’ve been talking about vicarious trauma or self care. Would the others of you have had conversations around vicarious trauma or self care if you didn’t have the box?

lines.speaker: Participant 8
lines.text: Yes. Self care. I enjoy self care. You have to have it with the profession that we’re in.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Definitely. And where would you get that information? Is that something that you do on your own, or something you'd look for at a professional organization, where would you go?

lines.speaker: Participant 8
lines.text: On my own. Message, a day out, just to enjoy myself. Those are the kinds of things I like.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That sounds good. Thanks, Lorraine. Samina I saw you take your mic off too. 244

lines.speaker: Participant 7
lines.text: Okay, it’s recreation. I mean, you know there is a weekend. That’s very….that’s self care by itself.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Absolutely. We need 3 or 4 day weekends sometimes, but the weekends! Absolutely… to have some downtime.

lines.speaker: Participant 7
lines.text: But I love my job, and honestly my job does not….I have never felt burned out because of my job or my students. But this year, all these trainings, all this mental health information and all that being given to us…that is burning my brains out.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah. So information over a load, especially around mental health. Is it kind of the needs that students and families have?

lines.speaker: Participant 7
lines.text: I don't know different policies, you know, the legislature. They're just enforcing different things, and they're pushing it in schools. And then, of course, counselors. Maybe next year will be different. Next year you ask the question and I’ll say ‘yes!’

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah. Anybody else?

lines.speaker: Participant 10
lines.text: It does help me, the box. But I think, again as I said, just going back to re-listen, to remind myself to really continue to do self care. Which for me means getting out and exercising and riding my bike, because I had stooped doing that for a while. And I can’t tell you why. But I stopped. And I realized I wasn’t feeling as rested and relaxed when I stopped. So I think for me, going back and listening to the video will be very helpful because I love to listen, and it just motivates me.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah. Absolutely. Deborah, where would you go [for support with self care]? It sounds like you mostly kind of go to our own self or your own life for self care, would you go anywhere else to get support or information around vicarious trauma or self care?

lines.speaker: Participant 10
lines.text: Well, I do attend the national conferences. And that for me is very helpful because it’s a larger group. And whenever I’ve attended a conference, I’ve always found one training that talks about self care. And I make sure that I’ve attended that particular session. So yeah, I do look at other options. And now that we’re traveling more, I can do more. Because when we were not able to, you’re kind of stuck to your own devices. So it’s getting better. As I said, I’m a work in progress.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, thanks Deborah.  Louisa, where do you go for information on self care and vicarious trauma, just out of curiosity?

lines.speaker: Participant 9
lines.text: Usually, let's say once a year, well lets start from the beginning. I’m on facebook, I’m there on a daily basis. So I see interesting topics from reliable sources, because I follow the National Mental Health…several associations. When I see something interesting, I save it. And whenever I have time, I go through it. But when I see a topic of interest, let's say, and it's a weekend, I go back to my library from when I got ... .I have a small library at home with all my books from when I got my two masters. I have masters in school counseling and one in mental health counseling. So I go back to read what literature says about it. I prefer facebook, it's more pleasant, it has pictures. But if I really want to study something and understand it, I have to go back to whatever materials I had before. And sometimes the articles, meaning peer reviewed ones. I’m just… I really like to read and I like to study so I’m that kind of person.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Thanks, that's good! Everybody kind of prefers information in different ways, and I think you know, everybody wants to be able to trust the information that they're getting so I think that's helpful to think about too. Absolutely. So you've all kind of talked about [how] this topic is very relevant to the work you do. So I might skip number 7. We've talked a little bit about the materials that were most useful to you, or less useful,  and the kinds of information. Was there anything that you didn't mention about the materials in the box in terms of what you used or didn’t used, liked or didn’t like, that you didn’t say already?

lines.speaker: Participant 8
lines.text: I have a question. What was the purpose of that card? [There’s] a card there, a resource card.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: The resource USB Card…

lines.speaker: Participant 8
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: So the USB, it has a few different resources in it related to the school district’s Wellness Initiative from 211 in Palm Beach. So I think it's meant to be something for you if you're looking for ways to kind of get support or find support. I don't think it's meant for students or anything, but I think they are resources for you.

lines.speaker: Participant 7
lines.text: So how do we use it?  Do I take that little piece out, or do we insert the card somewhere?

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: I think you stick it in the computer like a USB.  You have a place in your computer you can put it. I haven't seen it…

lines.speaker: Participant 7
lines.text: So you take that piece out!?

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Oh, so is it like an actual card… like a flat card?

lines.speaker: Participant 7
lines.text: It’s connected to a card inside. Not as an extra piece, but part of the card. But you can see a little cut out. I was too nervous to pull it out

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, I haven't seen the box for a little while. Sorry, guys, or I would have a more direct answer. But it goes in your computer and it'll open up like a file. It shows up as if you've inserted like a USB type drive kind of thing, and it has the files on it for you.

lines.speaker: Participant 7
lines.text: So we have to find out how to use that?

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: The only thing I can think of is if you wanted to contact LSIS and ask them for support or if you have a colleague who has a little more tech knowledge maybe they can help you figure out where on your computer you put it.  I know some computers have little things that kind of pop out from the side that you can put the card in I think.

lines.speaker: Participant 7
lines.text: I don't know where to put that connector..

lines.speaker: Participant 9
lines.text: There is. It’s folded. You unfold it and plug it into the computer.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Okay. So Samina, if you… I don't know if you have it with you. But if we finish and you wanted to show me I could probably try to help you.. or Luisa could. We'll finish up, and then we'll take a quick look with the screen share and see if we can help you out. Thanks Samina.

lines.speaker: Participant 9

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: What was your experience or kind of initial reaction to receiving the school counselor care and support box?

That was my initial thought when I received the box

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Sounds good. And for you, was there anything surprising about the box, about the materials, or anything you received?

I was able to learn a little more, and to categorize better what I had experienced, and not just pool it all into [being a counselor]. Maybe I need to do more self care or I’m becoming overwhelmed because of burnout and stuff like that.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley

But were you familiar with what it was? Maybe [just called it] something else?  Or was that new for you, for example.

lines.speaker: Participant 11

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: So, being able to kind of put words to the experience or feelings that you've had in your career. Was there anything else in the box that was newer for you, or that was helpful information?
