lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text:
That’s okay that’s good to know, we definitely want to know [everything]  Thanks, Dionne. 

 Pamela for you. ..The first question was what was your initial experience or reaction when you got the box?

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text: In all honesty, I originally thought it was a box for tools for studentss.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: You know almost everybody has said that. It took people a moment to realize it was for them so no worries!  Dionne just said the same thing, that she thought it was for her students. 0:08:30.650--> 00:09:20.220

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text: But yeah, I realized when I heard and saw the video: I was like, ‘oh, that's for us!’ I thought: ‘okay, this is neat!’ Cause normally, we don't have anything that's counselor focused, because we are the people that help students deal with trauma. And yet we, too, are affected by the same information that we hear. Even if indirectly, because it can be overwhelming and taxing to hear some of the things that you hear on a daily basis. Sometimes you do need a moment to figure out how to compartmentalize what’s going on in your world versus what’s happening with the students. Then not letting the two worlds collide and affect your overall emotional wellbeing.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Absolutely. And I don't know if this is relevant to you both…but in some of the past groups, some of the counselors were saying that the teachers often need a lot of support, too, and that you're not just there for the students, but you're also there to help teachers. Do you guys have the same experience?

lines.speaker: Participant 11
lines.text: Yeah. Definitely!

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: For you, Pamela –  and then we'll move on to question 3 –. Was there anything in the box that was new to you, or different than what you've learned before, in terms of the information or content presented?

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text: Well for the information  - I've heard these things before. The only thing is,  is that it's nice, because everything is in that one box. So you kind of know where it is, and you know to reference it when you need it. So normally you know these things, but you don’t practice these things. It’s like a refresher. And it’s right there. So you know where it is. You know to utilize it when you need to utilize it

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: So it’s kind of like a self care, package, or a break - a pause - from when you're feeling that way. Gotcha. Was there any information in there that was something you would say is extremely helpful versus not helpful?

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text: I would say,  I actually like the perspective cards. Personally, I'm a visual person. So I like to see things -  pictures, image - and I like to learn more information about what the [photgraph really means]. What’s in a a photograph, they would say: “whats in a photograph?” So I like things like that. I like visuals. It takes my mind to a different space. It takes me away from what’s happening in the moment. It helps. I like things like that. I think that the post its for the mediations are good, but because I’m more visual, it’s like I can read it and know what to do, but it’s just the way my mind thinks - I like pictures. I like things to come together visually for me. I would like more visuals! I know it sounds weird. I don’t know how you could do that on a post it, but that’s just the way I process things.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: . Well, if you throw it out there.. I'm not the creative person. I just the I compile and report the information, and I share it with the people who are more creative. But yeah, I think that that's okay feedback. I will take any and all suggestions. And a Dr. Spencer appreciates any suggestions because she just wants to be the best at her job and support people the way that they need help. So yeah, absolutely. Thanks for sharing that. So, the next question – and whoever wants to go fist, it’s totally fine – how did the box impact the way the you feel about vicarious trauma or self care.

lines.speaker: Participant 11
lines.text: I can go. As I said before, vicarious trauma, that term was new to me. But knowing about what it is, it’s something that I have experienced. It just brought more awareness to me. Because sometimes I feel something and I will just dismiss it as “okay well maybe I’m thinking too much into this, or not processing it properly.” I’ve been known to be a people pleaser. So then I wonder if it's that I’m not doing enough self care. So when this term was introduced, I’m reading more about it, and really considering my personal experience, and what I’ve been privy to in this field. And then I realize, this is something that I cannot ignore. I have accepted it, and I know that I have to pay more attention to self care.

lines.speaker: Participant 11
lines.text: Yes, Definitely!

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Thanks Dionne! What about you, Pamela, how would you describe the impact of the box and how you feel about vicarious trauma or self-care?

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text: I agree with Dionne. I agree. I wasn’t aware of what vicarious trauma was. Actually hearing more about what it is and how it impacts us as professionals, I was like oh this makes perfect sense. So I definitely think it’s good to be aware of that, because again, we can’t be helpful to others if we aren’t helping ourselves. Sort of like that old scenario with the plane, you can’t provide oxygen to someone else if you didn’t put your mask on first.  It’s so true. We forget to take care of ourselves. The daily mantra of life, ‘I just have to do what I have to do’, or ‘someone needs me right now’ and you just go. But you don’t really take the time to eat, to think about what you need to get through your day. Maybe you had a rough night and you are coming into work and you have to put on a mask. Really, deep down inside, you need a moment, you need a space to debrief or to cry away from the view of others. To kind of gather yourself. I think that it’s nice to try to have something to remind yourself that you need time for you. I have a problem of kind of burning both ends of the candlestick so to speak, where I tend to try to do everything. I’m like the jack of all trades, which means I’m the master of none. Because I’m so busy trying to do everything on my plate! All the tasks. And the tasks never end. Because you have a plan, and you go to work, and you know how that goes – your plan means nothing. At all.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: And then there's 10 people knocking on your door before you've gotten out of your car in the parking lot, right?

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text: Basically! Your name is on the loudspeaker. They are calling for you. So I always say to myself, you know ‘how can I do this??” All these people are depending on me. What am I going to do. And I neglect me. If don’t get me together first, I can’t do anything else. So I think this is good to really remind yourself to check on you first. Then you can go about what you need

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Definitely. So it kind of like reignited the awareness of the importance of self care and helped you to make a a mental plan hopefully to do something - even if it's small - to take good care of yourself.

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text: Absolutely! It it just helps.  Because I was like, Wow! There's something for us! To put things in a place where we can find something for ourselves. I thought that was very unique.

lines.speaker: Participant 11
lines.text: Yeah I agree. I'm listening to Pamela and thinking “is she in my head!?” Because as she was saying, I’m like yeah how can I get more hours in my day to see this student or that student, to get this project done. Sometimes I go without lunch. And I still don’t have enough time to get things done. And then a teacher will look at me and be like “Ms. Smith this and this is going on and I asked you to see about it and you are not even taking it on, because this is important!” And I’m like, okay, it frustrating to me. Because I want to be there. I want to assist. But then I feel overwhelmed. And I feel like everything is just coming down on me. And we are the only school counselors, so it’s not as if there is someone else within my [department]. I mean we have our mental health worker and BHP, but there is no one else who is doing the same type of job that we are that we can go to and just let it all out. So this box it actually helped because what I do is I take thos sticky notes and I work wihat th it, and I stick it on my computer. My office is different from my classroom, so I’ll stick it up, and that will be a reminder to me. Like you know what - all of this is going on, it feels like the space is going to burn down, but I need to focus on this for me. I need to do some deep breathing. I need to calm my mind before I extend myself to be more useful to those around me.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, I think that's great to hear. And I'm glad the box was supportive of you taking that moment and recognizing the importance of taking care of yourself first. I always think you can't pour from an empty cup, you know so you have to kind of fill your cup up, even if it's 5% of volume at a time. Right? Yeah thank you guys for sharing that. I don’t know if this is relavent to you, but one things that’s been difficult is, other counselors have said the box is especially relevant right now with policy changes, and violence in the news, and those kind of things. Have you found similar issues, with relavnacy for the importance of self care and vicarious trauma right now? Or is it mostly because of the demands of your immediate position or job?

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text:
I'll answer. I think that, I know that politically the climate has gotten more crazy with everything that is happening. There are changes left and right. I mean, I can’t keep up with all the changes. It’s more on us as educators because the changes always trickle down to our system. So that’s one thing that can cause issues. Because these things affect us not just as professionals, but it affects all of us in our lives. The decisions that are made. School safety is a big thing now, which is another level of stress. Making sure our kids are safe. [Wondering] am I doing the right thing? You know, everything you do, you wonder - did you do the right thing. Did you lock the door behind you. There is always a worry. So that’s added to everything else. So I think having a space to clear your mind and knowing that its you first. Getting that in order so you can make sure that you are on point. Because if you are not focused, and you don’t have a space to create calm, you are starting to forget now. Because you are all over the place.

Again, I’ve seen situations where educators are so burnt out that it starts to be the simple things they are forgetting. Like misplacing something important. So I definitely understand that part. Also I want to talk about the pandemic too. That was a big toll on everyone emotionally. I think if I had something like this at that time it would’ve helped me a lot. Especially when we were all remote it was very challenging and stressful.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: I need like 50 post its during the pandemic! I was teaching online too for college students, not elementary or anything. I think you guys got the harder job.

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text: Listen. They think it’s easy to do that. I’m telling you, anybody that knows what it is like teaching kids behind a screen. It's not the same. You need so many different activities and strategies. You need to destress and meditate because it’s not easy. They thought that at home we were relaxing. No. It was not. It was challenging at best.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah! Thanks, Pamela. Dionne do you want to add anything to that?

lines.speaker: Participant 11
lines.text:
I think that also the policy changes increased behavior issues since the pandemic until now. I see that even the teacher in my school, they are stress level has heightened. And because they have all this [pressure] in getting the curriculum done and having the kids…

One teacher was telling me they had to do a topic that would normally take three weeks in one week. And it was so stressful for her to get it done. Doubly stressful for the students. And then when they start acting out, its like a rippling effect because nobody is settled. And then that trickles down to me, and there are more behavior complaints and more referrals. And it can feel overwhelming. But, as Palema said, once you are able to find that calming space, being able to reflect and look at these little sticky notes that I have, and remember that once I’m okay, I can then attend to things around me. And understand that this is not a personal attack on me. It is not my place to try and solve everything. But instead to be a supportive hand. It just helps me to remember that.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Thanks, Dionne. So it sounds like you guys have had conversations around vicarious trauma and self-care, even if that wasn’t the words you used. So if you would have had those conversations, where would you have gone for support or information about vicarious trauma or self care before you received the box. Would you go to a professional orginization? Would you go to the internet for example? Would you go to a colleague? Just out of curiosity..

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text: Well now I have a word. To describe what I was feeling. I didn’t put the term with what I was feeling. But before that yes, you know, I didn't understand what I did. Well, now, I have a word to describe what I was feeling. But before that, I knew that as counselors we need counseling too. I’m an advocate for counseling, I think that it is helpful to have someone to talk to -  not a family member or friend who is not a objective - to kind of really help you to process and guide you. Like you said, it’s self guidance. I always was seeking counseling for myself. Just to help me me process life. And give me some tools that I need to kind of overcome challenges without the judgement. You know how that is.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Sometimes you don't want to go to your mom or your sister. You need someone who doesn’t know you.

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text: They don’t understand! They can’t understand. They are like why don’t you just ‘do this’ its so simple! And I’m like - I don’t think you understand. you have to be in the environment to understand what it is. Educators know. But the thing with educators is, everybody has a different plight in that building. They have their own problems. They don’t have time to hear you complaining because they already have a million things on their table. So they don’t want to hear it. They’ll say yes to you, and okay. Go do what you have to do. Go do your job - that’s what people say. They are thinking it. They won’t say it but they might be thinking it. So I think that counseling would have been an option. However, I think it is difficult to get counseling sometimes because there is a lot of things involved: Money - its very expensive- and Time - we already don’t have a lot of time. So what can I do now to get what I need in the moment if I need it. So that helps. The box helps in that way. It’s something I can utilize in that moment. I don’t have to make a phone call. I don’t have to go on a computer or go to a center. Eventually that can be an option, but this is something that you can deal with right now in your space.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That’s great. It’s kinda like an intermediary resource. And you can deicide do you need further assistance or do you just need to be triaged? Is it just the blood pressure or do you need the the vaccination!?

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text: Exactly.

lines.speaker: Participant 11
lines.text: So let me say this first. Before I heard about vicarious trauma, I would not have really gone out trying to define it or put a label to it. Because I just clumped it all in to self care and burnout. Now that I know that it is a real separate experience that we have, I definitely do agree with Pemala when she said that counseling is important for us to have as a resource to turn to. Everyone is on youtube so I can find videos to try and get more information about it. Definitely the box brought awareness. I’ll be honest, I haven’t finished reading the book yet, but that together with other resources to build on the information that I now know exists. That is a real situation that I have to address.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text:
Thank you guys. So we’ve kind of worked through like 5, 6, and 7 a little bit, so let’s go ahead to 8 and 9. You’ve talked a little bit about the materials but just to reinforce - which materials were most helpful and which were least useful?

Do you have recommendations for improving the box? 
And if you want to add on - what other topics outside of the box, if we were to do a round 2 at some point in the future, what might you want to see or would be helpful to your job?

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text:
So for me I would say to answer that question. You know. I think the box is amazing, of course. But because I think i'm all about people being different learners and receiving information differently - and I am a visual spatial learner, because I like to see things with my eyes and paint a picture in my head of a story. I just like a lot of visuals. Maybe it’s the elementary school counselor in me. I’d love something like a poster. Maybe a video image. That’s why I loved the intro video. I loved it because the presenter has come to my school so I was excited to see her on a video. Secondly, I did like the images. The video was really well put together. I loved it. It was really nice to watch it and kind of get an understanding of vicarious trauma. So that appealed to me. The video appealed to me the most. The perspective cards appealed to me also because the images and the stories behind images appeal to me. The post it notes I don’t mind, but because of the way I perceive information, I just more enjoyed the visual spatial. Everybody is different right. Some might be audio learners, who may want something like a meditation track. That might be something that could be in a second box. Something you can listen to. Some music, some sounds, some mediation instructions, calming soothing sounds. 

So for example, I know during the pandemic, what appealed to my daughter when she was overwhelmed with the idea of being home and being away from everybody, we would pretend that we were traveling without really traveling. We would put on airplane noises and act like we were going somewhere. We would sit down and act like we were in a plane and we do that pretend. That was realy soothing and fun for her. She is a child but you know adults, we are advanced in our thinking but we still need some of the same things. Sometimes it’s back to basics with us. so I think that for the next box, maybe some more visuals. Maybe an audio piece to help along with the post its. And you could put on your own music of course, but maybe in school you can’t listen to certain types of songs, buf it it’s something that has been vetted and it’s soothing, I don’t think any educator would walk in and have a problem with soothing music. 

Like a guided meditation.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah I know sometimes I can find videos with a guided for, for whatever she is is ailing me at that moment.

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text: Something to that effect. And it could be good for kids too. For students too. But really for yourself first. But if you happen to be playing it and a student comes you might be able to practice it with a student because it’s something that you can both utilize in that moment. .

lines.speaker: Participant 11
lines.text: I love the idea of an audio because it helps change your mood and your perspective. One of the things that I loved in this box was the introduction video. I think it was encapsulating. So it was sectioned off. It was orginized. It was engaging. And it really just brought the understanding of what this box was about in a short space of time. I really appreciated that. I love the sticky notes, as I said, because it reminds me of what is important - taking care of me before I extend myself. The perspective cards were helpful when I read the back of them, but the pictures didn’t really resonate with me. Maybe I’m not realy an art-focused type of person. I do like visuals. But maybe if they were different photos. I think that answers the question.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That’s good! What other topics would you guys want to learn about, or see? What would that you would benefit from in terms of a box. If we were to do another round in the future. Not me, I’m just a background helper. But if they were to put together a box.

lines.speaker: Participant 11
lines.text: I like the idea of the self care and the options and the different things that we can have as a resource to get help. Preferably if we can get more online assistance. If she can put links to different self help videos. Because sometimes, yes, I know I can go to counseling. But if I can get a video that I can look at or some resource online that I can get that experience from that would be helpful and engaging as well.

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text:
You know I think self-help is definitely something that should be ongoing. I think that being able to maybe learn some more strategies. Maybe add more activities that we can actually practice. And I like to do activities that can help me. But, if I can do activities that help me and its also appropriate to help someone else, like a student…that’s the best of both worlds. I could use it for me and help you learn how to do it. This is another tool and strategy that you can put away for when you need. That’s how I like to work. It makes me function better. I also think, I know this is going to sound weird, because we think as a professional we should have these things down pat, but organization is another issues. 

I want to say I’m organized. But I always think, could there be an easier way for me to organize and manage my time differently. Not to say that it’s going to help me do way more because that’s not realistic. You can be as organized as you want to be, but you can’t predict the school environment. You just cannot. Because these are human beings that are coming in with things daily, and you don’t know what happened last night, this morning, you just can’t control those extraneous factors and variables in a day. But I would say if there was some ideas about how to organize and manage the time as professionals so that we can compartmentalize things in a different way. Maybe go back to some times. I like to find different ways to learn to organize myself. 

It’s weird to say but it’s hard. I used to work in the high school level for many years. When I was working on a high school level, I had to come up with tracking systems that made it easier for me to track student graduation progress. It made it so much easier for me. And it was something that me and my colleague, who was very organized did together. She was very organized and I used to admire that. She was stressed. Don’t get me wrong she was stressed. But she was like look I need to do this so that it doesn’t overwhelm me. She had to find ways for the work not to overwhelm her. So she sat and planned and came up with a way to do a checkbox. So maybe something we can do that’s a checkbox, that is categorized, and maybe something that can be added to the next box, I’m not saying to this one, to kind of not only help you do self care but some better planning. So that you can minimize some of the overwhelming-ness.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: .Yeah! I think it’s a good idea. It reminds me…somebody else had asked for a politically vetted resource library. Things that you can just put on a usb or have in a file on your computer and know that this is the material you need. They were talking about the changes and not knowing what you can use and not use, or confusion with how to use things. So that made me think a little bit about that. I know other people also mentioned things that you can use with your students that might be for you but that you can apply with other people too. Those are great suggestions.

lines.speaker: Participant 12
lines.text: Exactly. Yeah. Exactly!

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Is there anything else that popped into your mind that you want to share that you weren't asked, or anything before we say goodbye today.

lines.speaker: Participant 11
lines.text: No

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text:
sounds good. Well I appreciate your time so much. I know it's a it's a busy time. It's a busy week, and we're getting closer to the end of the school semester. I think i'm a little closer with that, then you guys, but I will send you all the positive vibes. I really appreciate you guys and it was good meeting you! Let me put my email in the chat just in case you need it for any reason. Or you can look me up if you ever have any questions about the evaluation. Otherwise, Dr. Spencer is your main contact for content and stuff. I’m just in the school of social work, I teach and do research and support community agencies. 

That is it you guys! Tues 5/30 at 6pm Focus Group

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text:
The answers are anonymous and always aggregated, combined with other people's responses. All right. I'm just gonna put a couple of questions in the chat in case you like to look ahead, and because some of them are a little more repetitive.

The first question is what was your experience using the support box?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: I thought it was a really cool concept, because counselor’, mental health and counselors’ care kind of fall second and falls 0 when it comes to admin. It was cool to have a reminder to think of yourself first. Fill your own cup before you can fill others kind of thing. I went through the box with my site supervisor, we got them together. It was a cool conversation starter for us, because I was asking her, “have you ever gotten anything like this before”. It was a cool conversation starter between us. And then when you opened the box there was that video to do. We watched that video together, that was really nice. Overall, I would just say that it catered to a lot of different attention styles. If I was more auditory there was things I could listen to, if I liked to read it more there were things I could read, if I’m a more physical learner there are things I can manipulate, it was really interactive in a lot of different ways.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: : Awesome. Thank you for sharing that. I'm just curious, since you're finishing up your internship. Did you learn about self care a lot in school, or is that somewhat of a newer or less talked about topic for you?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: I would say it was heavily talked about. I just graduated from FAU. The school counseling cohort is with the mental health. So a lot of our curriculum aligns with what you are familiar with. Self care was definitely talked about a lot. We talked about having supervision of your own so that you can debrief things. We talked about always relying on other counselors if you are ever feeling confused about something and wondering where do I go, what should I do. We talked about always taking your weekends and setting healthy boundaries. That was very much talked about in a lot of different classes.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, how did the box overlap with some of the things that you have learned.. Some of the people that we've talked to went through school a little longer ago, and self-care was not as talked about.. So I'm curious for you, how well does the box align with your training?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: I would say like 70 to 80%, because the box was very heavy on the word trauma, and I don't think that that is really talked about with the self-care side of things. The ideas that there is secondary trauma you can inherit. That wasn’t at least explicitly said in my program. I don’t think anyone would balk at that if you said it. But it isn’t an explicitly said topic. But I think that what the box said about what you should do to help with secondary trauma aligns with what my program said to do to take care of yourself.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That's good. So the messaging was pretty consistent. But the box focused more on some of the things that you experience that are more potentially harmful, or specific signs or symptoms?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: Yeah! That was one of those really helpful things. When I went through t with my supervisor, she was like,  I've never really thought about that word trauma with what we go through sometimes. But she's like, “but it's true!” You do see some hard stuff. And it does really affect you.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Definitely. Was that  new for you, thinking about the secondary traumatic stress? I'm transitioning a little bit. But was any of it new, or was it more like, “Huh, like, I haven't thought about it” How did that hit you?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: I guess I haven't really thought about it in the school counselor sense.. My background I worked in mental health before this.  I was a mobile crisis responder, where I spoke to people experiencing suicidal thoughts in jails and hospitals. So I had heavy training with secondary trauma. And so it wasn't new to me individually as a person. But I had never really thought about it in the school counseling role.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: How would it be different? How do you see that information is different within each role? Kind of thinking about like the framing of the box? I'm a social worker so I can empathize with the mobile crisis stuff.

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text:
Yeah, I would say that with crisis, you're much more responsible for people. I would speak to people, and then I would use that information to then decide, what do they need? Am I going to have them involuntarily hospitalize? Or am I going to send them home? Whatever happens falls on me. So there was a lot of training about how you deal with that.  And how do you cope with that?

Whereas school counseling is less pressure. We just kind of guide, and it is up to the students to do what they will. There is less responsibility for outcomes. Where there is less liability for their choices, you are way more invested with school counseling. With crises I would meet people once, mayber twice. And on the second time, that’s hard because you don’t want to meet them twice. With school counseling you are so much more invested. I have known people for months and I’m so invested I can’t imagine knowing them for 4 years, knowing people from freshman to senior year and then seeing them fail!?  Ugh! That would gut you. That’s just for nomal things they fail at. Not even for when actual trauma happens or actual hard things happen. You are so invested and in it and you feel like they are a part of you. They are an extension of your own children!

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah! So you have a high level of empathy, and building that relationship for you makes it higher stakes. You're more connected. So you feel  more sympathy sometimes than empathy. I would say.

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: Yeah, for sure.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Do you think there is information in there that was more helpful or less helpful when you think about the types of information that were presented for the context of working with children in schools.

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: I think that.. helpful. I actually have the book. The book! I like the book. I brought an example of the little post it notes. Cute, but not as helpful. Because it’s the same thing over and over again. It’s meant to be a reminder for myself and something I can stick on a coworkers desk. But you read one and you’ve literally read them all. It’s all the same thing on a notepad. So I would say less helpful. But, everything on the post its is helpful. Nothing on it is not helpful.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: You like the idea but maybe you it to be different in some ways? Is there something you would want different about the little posted notes.

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: I don't know….There was variety,  because there was like 6 of these, or however many in the box. So maybe having the information from the 6 pads interchanged within each pad. So when you flip it there is a different note on the second page and you are like “Oh! what is this!”

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That sounds good! I always want to be careful about like putting words in your mouth!

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: No, I appreciate it.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: So for you the book was useful. What was helpful about the book? Was there something specific you like about it?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text:
I'll be honest. I haven't finished the book. I did start the book. I wanted it to be something. I finished by my internship, but the internship has more than enough going on. 

However, I really really like that it engages with specific mental health concepts. Because school counseling deals with mental health on the fringe. They are very clear that you may be a mental health support, but you are not a therapist. You aren’t there to use specific terminology, you are not there to help them figure out what they do or don’t have. That’s not what you are there for. You are there as a support to help with other mental health counselors like a therapist or case workers. I say that to say that I really like that this gives specifics, first of all. Because, I have mental training, but that’s me, I’m not all school counselors. School counselors in general come from an education background not a mental health background. So I like that this gives a lot of mental health specific information. Like here is what this word means, here is what it can look like. Here is what is can look like for students, or for yourself - mentally, physically, emotionally. Here is specfic information for that. And, here is how you can use that in your specific role. I think that was very very helpful. And I also liked first of all, that the book is really interactive. I’ll say that. It is different than sitting and reading a chapter book. I really like that it’s interactive and you can kind of apply it to your experiences or future experiences. 

I also liked that going along with the specific definitions and examples, I liked that there was always the application of here is how it could affect you. Here is how it could affect your students. And here is what to do with that information. Because I think lot of resources I’ve experienced so far miss that last step. A lot of things are information heavy: here is what you need to know!” And then I feel a lot of the times, what do I do with that though! I’ve identified that, cool…but now what!

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text:
Exactly. Sometimes that's how I feel about ACE’s training. I can empathize with that. The application is important right?

00:11:04.950 —->00:11:06.699 
Participant 13: Yes! Yes! What do I do with that?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: I would say that using the word trauma really helped. I wasn’t really prepared to apply what I learned with crisis into this role but I think it made me realize I’m going to have to do that. I’m really lucky to have the box early into my career because I can kind of set things right from the beginning. Whereas someone like my site supervisor has been doing this for ten years and feels like “it hasn’t failed me yet” - so why would I change. So I think it has really helped with just being aware of how their experiences, hard experiences and even not that hard experiences -they don’t think it’s hard when they fail - being aware of how to manage myself in that. Knowing that I can’t shoulder all of their choices and their burdens and their responsibilities. And how even if I find myself doing it- what can I do then to stop it to revert it and to calm myself. So I would say yes [ there has been an impact]

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: That makes sense.. When you think of …when we talked about your site superviso.., do you think that the challenges that you face are different than what she faces because of your experience, or something about the work that you do like. Is there a way that maybe the box would be helpful in different ways to people at different levels or types of experience. I ask that because you have a little bit of mental health experience. I know it’s kind of a deep thinking question. But when you talked about it you said she had a slightly different perspective on things. So I was just curious, do you think the box is differentially helpful?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: Great question! To be fair…she's a unique character. A different conversation for a different time. [Her reaction] was not personal to the box. They’re a difficult person to move on anything. For somebody with a mental health background versus not, or just somebody that’s been doing it a long time versus somebody that hasn’t….The hard thing at least that I’ve seen so far and that I’ll probably continue to see is that people that have been doing this a long time since pre-covid, since pre-socio emotional learning, since pre ACEs training, since pre-All of that, have a very different mindset and perspective on kid’s beheavior and on their own behavior than those that started after all of that. At least people that are in my generation. But you can learn at any point. But people who are in my ‘school of learning’ - I guess - I’ve noticed are much more willing to learn and flexible. You are going to introduce a concept like ACEs and we’re like “that makes sense! yeah!” and then we kind of move forward. While people pre-all of that are just kind of like (scoffs), “I haven’t seen any of that” and kind of just dismiss it. So I say that to say - I don’t know if the box can attract them. I don’t know!

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text:
Yeah, I was just curious if you had any any thoughts or insight about that. We've heard a little bit from different people that those who don’t have as much of a background with vicarious trauma or secondary trauma etc. the box can be really helpful because it kind of teaches something new. But then I had somebody who said ‘no it was a great refresher, I would take it anyway!” So we’re just trying to figure out if there are any kinds of trends…or what makes it helpful or less helpful for different people. 

But I do wonder. You mentioned that flexibility..sometimes being in stress makes you less flexible. But also maybe having a certain kind of training. These are all questions or implications, but just kind of thinking out loud as we talk. 

So I’m going to put the next round of questions up. For you, do you think you would have had these conversations about vicarious or secondary trauma if you didn’t use the box?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: With my site, supervisor?  No! 100% no!

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: So she wouldn’t have brought it up? Or you wouldn’t have brought it up?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: Neither. I don't think I would have thought to have asked, and she most definitely wouldn't have gotten that personal or anything.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, just not something that like you talk about. Can I ask, why do you think that would be? What is it about your work that maybe that wouldn't have come up?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: I think it's more about her as a person than it is the work. I think other people at that school were more than willing to share in that capacity. It was just kind of her as a person.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Is she very stoic? Or is she kind of like a serious person? What is it about her supervisory style? Because I think one thing that my social worker side says is that if the supervisor or if your boss doesn't like support you in something, than it's not going to happen on the ground level or with your clients, right? Or with your students. So I'm curious. What do you think is it about her than influences your work?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: I mean. One of the many reasons that I did not take a position in that school was that I just knew… like you just said is, if I couldn't get her on board it, 100% wasn't going to happen, no matter what it was I wanted to do. So, for that reason. It’s not that she’s so serious. It’s that she is just set. She is clearly of the opinion that she knows all that she needs to know and its her job to tell you all the information. And if you bring anything new to the table, that’s not helpful, that’s not relevant, clearly you don’t know enough to be telling her things. This is both to me and to other people. It’s just kind of her as a person.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: There's kind of a hierarchical or bureaucratic kind of approach to power structure. I don't know if those are the right words, but she kind of acts like she's the the supervisor - she's been doing this, and she knows what she's doing. That kind of thing?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: Yeah. And you could never bring up mistakes or alternatives. There was none of that. And what’s crazy is she wan’t even the supervisor of other people. She had a boss at the school. The lead supervisor wasn’t even her. So..

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, well, I think that's important. Being in environment where you do have people that have either real or perceived authority. So you are talking a little bit about having an enviornment that uspports you in self care too. I think that’s important. These things that would influence your ability to use the box effectively or not use the box effectively. Just if this is helpful or makes you think, other people we’ve talked to have brought up that often they were so overwhelmed by how stressed out the teachers sometimes were, that they felt like their job was really for the students but their unwritten job was to support the teachers. To them that was something overwhelming. A lot of people also talked about the political enviornment as something that kind of influenced their ability to use the box or have conversations or those kinds of things.

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: 1000% Yes.. I would 1,000% agree with all of that. Although I will say that this does go back to my FAU training and the trend of things, because they do talk at FAU about how the role of school counselor is to be an advocate and support for all. Everyone in the school! It doesn’t matter if it’s a student or the principal or the teachers or everyone in between. So they kind of prime you for that. They say that people are going to be coming into your office crying and it’s not going to be exclusive to 16 year olds. It’s going to be every one. I’m at a highschool by the way - that’s where I’m going to be. But it’s going to be everyone and you’re going to be shouldering a lot more than just the students. So you kind of go into that knowing it’s going to happen. And it’s already happened to me. It’s happened to me many times!

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: : Even on your internship, you saw features or support staff coming to your office?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: Yeah. I made a point to really develop good relationships with my teachers there. Because they are the backbone. They are the ones who make the school go round. If you don’t have them on your side, you don’t have anyone on your side. So that’s who I really wanted on my side, was the teachers.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Where do you get information besides from your school program on self care. If it wasn’t in your program or in the box do you think it is something you would think about after doing your internship?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: Probably not now, at this point. But maybe later if I started feeling burnt out? Maybe!?

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: So maybe if you weren’t prepared for it or you didn’t have something like the box you would probably wait until it was more of a reactive response?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: Probably. Yeah. Probably. I know that Palm Beach schools have a wellness teams that sounds out monthly emails about self care things as well - not that a lot of people read them. But..

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: But It’s a good idea! A good little reminder.

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: Yeah!

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: When you think of your prior career with mental health, and you’ve had conversations about vicarious trauma or self care, what have those conversations been like? I know you said that you felt more reliable. But what discussions specific to vicarious trauma or self care? What was different.

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: I mean, at crisis I had to go through a two months training on top of my degree and certification to even get into it. And part of that was very heavy about self care and vicarious trauma. Your days off are days off. We are not going to be calling you, and don’t call us kind of thing. There has to be a clear boundary, which is nice.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Is education different? Is your school counseling different from what you've seen?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: I mean yeah. I would say that no one - at least that I’ve seen so far, at least at my school - really acknowledges that most of the counselors are glued to their phones on the weekends. And they have to be. And they are checking on their kids post graduation. Because they have to be. They don’t really have the clear boundaries. Nobody acknowledges that. Or god forbid says not to do that.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah I think that’s really important to think about. Because working on the weekend, you aren’t neccisrarly getting payed a ton of money in an educational enviornment to be able to care for yourself in different ways. But yeah, that would be really tough.

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: So for me, there was one other girl at my old school, and she’s in her second year, so she’s also really fresh. And she was in the same boat as me. She was also like I don’t have email on my phone, I’m not thinking about this on the weekend. No. She was like no. I’m going to end up like them - all burnt out - if I do that. So I think it is becoming more and more of a trend to try and set a healthy boundry. But it’s hard. It’s hard. And I’m sure if I check in with her in five years and myself in five years things may be different. Once you see kids start from freshman to senior year, that may be different. I don’t know.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text:
Yeah it’s interesting. I wish we could talk to you in 3 years right!?

The next question for you is how relevant is this topic for you? And because we’ve already hit that yeah this is pretty relevant, because you get so invested with them and you see their outcomes…I’m going to get a bit at the last question, but what would help this box even more relavent to the role of a school counselor based on your experiences. Is there anything you would add or adjust or take away to make the box more helpful or more effective?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: Yeah. I know that the boxes tailored for school counselors to care for school counselors, but I would almost include students in on the conversation, too. Some kind of way to say, like we are people, too. And we are dealing with our own things, too. Kind of like the post it notes. Something to include students too. I don’t know. That’s what I would do I think.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: A lot of people actually mentioned something they can actually do with students. We thought this was interesting. Speaking for LSIS herre, but we want the box to be for school counselors, but also school counselors are looking for tools and things they can apply to make their jobs easier. So that’s really good feedback. That this is for you and this is for your students. I think one person even like opened the box and thought “oh, this is for me!?’

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text:
My supervisor! My supervisor when she opened it was like ‘wait, wait!’ 

Even like some kind of activity maybe. Like if you have ever done the ACEs test yourself kind of thing. Maybe something like that. Have I experienced these kind of things? And if your score is this or you’ve done this, then here is something in the box that you can do. Activities maybe, I don’t know.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah. So I like the idea.Kind of a self care personal check in, quiz, or questionnaire.

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: Yeah, yeah! And even then you could use that with students if you wanted to. That kind of thing.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Any by activities do you mean thing that you do if you are feeling burned out? Like suggestions? Or things you can do with you students?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: I was saying more activities as in a self score quiz. Or maybe a coloring thing. Something where I see my results. Because there are so many practical applications already in the box. So just something telling you, if your results are x here is y that you can do with that. Directly pairing them already. Rather than, I have to read the book and I have to decide forr myself and pull out of here what am I going to use and what is relevant to me. Some kind of activity telling me ‘here is where you’ve landed, and here is what we have for you.’ “For more information, read the book!

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: I think they call that things to tailor that outcome to the person. Is that what you mean? Making it more personalized?

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: Yes! Exactly! Something to make it personalized! Thank you.

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: I was trying to think of the word for it. But ‘tailoring’ is how you can tailor mental health interventions for people with different problems, or how you can tailor parenting advice to people who are dealing with specific challenges, that kind of thing. Tailoring your need to the activity.

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text: Or even just a reference sheet, you know!? Have you experience this? If so, go to chapter three. Have you experienced this, go to chapter whatever. I think that would’ve probably been helpful for people more like my supervisor, who were like, I’m not going to sift through all this information to try and figure it out for myself. But there’s something telling them, like ‘oh I have experienced that’ or ‘I did go through that, or I’ve watched someone else go through that” - let me just be curious, what would they say to do?

lines.speaker: Morgan Cooley
lines.text: Yeah, kind of like a roadmap. Yeah, with all the activities, here are ways that you could use it if you're dealing with these things. Good idea. Yeah, I know we have a box with LSIS that is for parents who need to talk to their children about substance use and substance use disorders, and a couple of the parents said the materials were great -  but I would’ve liked to know different ways to get the best of the box. Because we started here, and then we just have the attention span to get to there or whatever. It’s (the roadmap) a good idea! What matirials do you think were helpful? You mentioned the book is helpful, and the post it notes were maybe a little less helpful for you. Were there other parts of the box that were more or less helpful when you think about yourself or other people using the box.

lines.speaker: Participant 13
lines.text:

Because sometimes I feel something and I will just dismiss it as “okay well maybe I’m thinking too much into this, or not processing it properly.” I’ve been known to be a people pleaser. So then I wonder if it's that I’m not doing enough self care. So when this term was introduced, I’m reading more about it, and really considering my personal experience, and what I’ve been privy to in this field. And then I realize, this is something that I cannot ignore. I have accepted it, and I know that I have to pay more attention to self care.

annotations.annotation: Participant 12 wasn’t aware of vicarious trauma before using the box and notes that they think it is important and good to know about; notes that professionals like themselves often feel the need to always help others and do what is on their plate and neglecting themselves and their needs in the process; notes that it is so nice to have a reminder to look after themselves because sometimes it is the professional who needs a moment of self care.

ref.speaker: Participant 12
ref.text: I agree with Dionne. I agree. I wasn’t aware of what vicarious trauma was. Actually hearing more about what it is and how it impacts us as professionals, I was like oh this makes perfect sense. So I definitely think it’s good to be aware of that, because again, we can’t be helpful to others if we aren’t helping ourselves. Sort of like that old scenario with the plane, you can’t provide oxygen to someone else if you didn’t put your mask on first.  It’s so true. We forget to take care of ourselves. The daily mantra of life, ‘I just have to do what I have to do’, or ‘someone needs me right now’ and you just go. But you don’t really take the time to eat, to think about what you need to get through your day. Maybe you had a rough night and you are coming into work and you have to put on a mask. Really, deep down inside, you need a moment, you need a space to debrief or to cry away from the view of others. To kind of gather yourself. I think that it’s nice to try to have something to remind yourself that you need time for you. I have a problem of kind of burning both ends of the candlestick so to speak, where I tend to try to do everything. I’m like the jack of all trades, which means I’m the master of none. Because I’m so busy trying to do everything on my plate! All the tasks. And the tasks never end. Because you have a plan, and you go to work, and you know how that goes – your plan means nothing. At all.

annotations.annotation: Participant 11 agrees that she her job is overwhelming and stressful, sometimes to the point where they need to skip lunch to manage the schedule and the needs of students; notes that it sometimes feels like everything is falling apart; notes that counselors don’t have a lot of assistance from others in the same position; says that the box – especially the sticky notes helped as a reminder to focus on themselves instead of trying to always save the situations first.

And then a teacher will look at me and be like “Ms. Smith this and this is going on and I asked you to see about it and you are not even taking it on, because this is important!” And I’m like, okay, it frustrating to me. Because I want to be there. I want to assist. But then I feel overwhelmed. And I feel like everything is just coming down on me. And we are the only school counselors, so it’s not as if there is someone else within my [department]. I mean we have our mental health worker and BHP, but there is no one else who is doing the same type of job that we are that we can go to and just let it all out. So this box it actually helped because what I do is I take thos sticky notes and I work wihat th it, and I stick it on my computer. My office is different from my classroom, so I’ll stick it up, and that will be a reminder to me. Like you know what - all of this is going on, it feels like the space is going to burn down, but I need to focus on this for me. I need to do some deep breathing. I need to calm my mind before I extend myself to be more useful to those around me.

annotations.annotation: Participant 12 notes that multiple factors are making the job of counselors more stressful and difficult, notes that the constant changes are hard to keep up with; notes that constant safety responsibilities also cause a lot of stress; addressees that they’ve seen such acute burnout that educators struggle to perform simple tasks; notes that this makes having a reminder and space to take care of yourself is crucial, and that without this self care educators become all over the place and unable to be useful.

ref.speaker: Participant 12
ref.text:
I'll answer. I think that, I know that politically the climate has gotten more crazy with everything that is happening. There are changes left and right. I mean, I can’t keep up with all the changes. It’s more on us as educators because the changes always trickle down to our system. So that’s one thing that can cause issues. Because these things affect us not just as professionals, but it affects all of us in our lives. The decisions that are made. School safety is a big thing now, which is another level of stress. Making sure our kids are safe. [Wondering] am I doing the right thing? You know, everything you do, you wonder - did you do the right thing. Did you lock the door behind you. There is always a worry. So that’s added to everything else. So I think having a space to clear your mind and knowing that its you first. Getting that in order so you can make sure that you are on point. Because if you are not focused, and you don’t have a space to create calm, you are starting to forget now. Because you are all over the place.

Again, I’ve seen situations where educators are so burnt out that it starts to be the simple things they are forgetting. Like misplacing something important. So I definitely understand that part. Also I want to talk about the pandemic too. That was a big toll on everyone emotionally. I think if I had something like this at that time it would’ve helped me a lot. Especially when we were all remote it was very challenging and stressful.

annotations.annotation: Participant 12 addressees that teaching remotely was really challenging and that they needed to use self care tools to get through it. 137

ref.speaker: Participant 12
ref.text: Listen. They think it’s easy to do that. I’m telling you, anybody that knows what it is like teaching kids behind a screen. It's not the same. You need so many different activities and strategies. You need to destress and meditate because it’s not easy. They thought that at home we were relaxing. No. It was not. It was challenging at best.

annotations.annotation: Participant 11 notes that the policy changes led to stress for the educators and left them feeling unsettled; addressees that it caused them to have to rush curriculums, and notes that this led to student stress and a ripple effect of being unsettled; notes that despite all of this, finding a place to be calm and take care of yourself is important; and notes that the box was a helpful tool to find this space and to remember they can’t solve everything.

ref.speaker: Participant 11
ref.text:
I think that also the policy changes increased behavior issues since the pandemic until now. I see that even the teacher in my school, they are stress level has heightened. And because they have all this [pressure] in getting the curriculum done and having the kids…

One teacher was telling me they had to do a topic that would normally take three weeks in one week. And it was so stressful for her to get it done. Doubly stressful for the students. And then when they start acting out, its like a rippling effect because nobody is settled. And then that trickles down to me, and there are more behavior complaints and more referrals. And it can feel overwhelming. But, as Palema said, once you are able to find that calming space, being able to reflect and look at these little sticky notes that I have, and remember that once I’m okay, I can then attend to things around me. And understand that this is not a personal attack on me. It is not my place to try and solve everything. But instead to be a supportive hand. It just helps me to remember that.

I’m an advocate for counseling, I think that it is helpful to have someone to talk to -  not a family member or friend who is not a objective - to kind of really help you to process and guide you. annotations.annotation: Participant 12 notes that they are a visual spatial learner and thus loved the perspective cards and the video and felt like these things really helped them; mentioned that while the other resources were good, they could be better enhanced by some visual aspects like a poster, as well as audio like soothing music or guided mediations.

ref.speaker: Participant 12
ref.text:
So for me I would say to answer that question. You know. I think the box is amazing, of course. But because I think i'm all about people being different learners and receiving information differently - and I am a visual spatial learner, because I like to see things with my eyes and paint a picture in my head of a story. I just like a lot of visuals. Maybe it’s the elementary school counselor in me. I’d love something like a poster. Maybe a video image. That’s why I loved the intro video. I loved it because the presenter has come to my school so I was excited to see her on a video. Secondly, I did like the images. The video was really well put together. I loved it. It was really nice to watch it and kind of get an understanding of vicarious trauma. So that appealed to me. The video appealed to me the most. The perspective cards appealed to me also because the images and the stories behind images appeal to me. The post it notes I don’t mind, but because of the way I perceive information, I just more enjoyed the visual spatial. Everybody is different right. Some might be audio learners, who may want something like a meditation track. That might be something that could be in a second box. Something you can listen to. Some music, some sounds, some mediation instructions, calming soothing sounds. 

So for example, I know during the pandemic, what appealed to my daughter when she was overwhelmed with the idea of being home and being away from everybody, we would pretend that we were traveling without really traveling. We would put on airplane noises and act like we were going somewhere. We would sit down and act like we were in a plane and we do that pretend. That was realy soothing and fun for her. She is a child but you know adults, we are advanced in our thinking but we still need some of the same things. Sometimes it’s back to basics with us. so I think that for the next box, maybe some more visuals. Maybe an audio piece to help along with the post its. And you could put on your own music of course, but maybe in school you can’t listen to certain types of songs, buf it it’s something that has been vetted and it’s soothing, I don’t think any educator would walk in and have a problem with soothing music. 

Like a guided meditation.

annotations.annotation: Participant 12 notes that self-care is critical; mentions that while this is about self-care, if there were some tools that they could also use with students, it would be a win-win; notes that this is how they work; also discusses that organization can be very tough in a hectic school environment, and that they’d like a box with tools for keeping organized.

ref.speaker: Participant 12
ref.text:
You know I think self-help is definitely something that should be ongoing. I think that being able to maybe learn some more strategies. Maybe add more activities that we can actually practice. And I like to do activities that can help me. But, if I can do activities that help me and its also appropriate to help someone else, like a student…that’s the best of both worlds. I could use it for me and help you learn how to do it. This is another tool and strategy that you can put away for when you need. That’s how I like to work. It makes me function better. I also think, I know this is going to sound weird, because we think as a professional we should have these things down pat, but organization is another issues. 

I want to say I’m organized. But I always think, could there be an easier way for me to organize and manage my time differently. Not to say that it’s going to help me do way more because that’s not realistic. You can be as organized as you want to be, but you can’t predict the school environment. You just cannot. Because these are human beings that are coming in with things daily, and you don’t know what happened last night, this morning, you just can’t control those extraneous factors and variables in a day. But I would say if there was some ideas about how to organize and manage the time as professionals so that we can compartmentalize things in a different way. Maybe go back to some times. I like to find different ways to learn to organize myself. 

It’s weird to say but it’s hard. I used to work in the high school level for many years. When I was working on a high school level, I had to come up with tracking systems that made it easier for me to track student graduation progress. It made it so much easier for me. And it was something that me and my colleague, who was very organized did together. She was very organized and I used to admire that. She was stressed. Don’t get me wrong she was stressed. But she was like look I need to do this so that it doesn’t overwhelm me. She had to find ways for the work not to overwhelm her. So she sat and planned and came up with a way to do a checkbox. So maybe something we can do that’s a checkbox, that is categorized, and maybe something that can be added to the next box, I’m not saying to this one, to kind of not only help you do self care but some better planning. So that you can minimize some of the overwhelming-ness.

I was a mobile crisis responder, where I spoke to people experiencing suicidal thoughts in jails and hospitals. So I had heavy training with secondary trauma. annotations.annotation: Participant 13 notes that while being a mobile counselor could be difficult because you are so responsible for the children school counseling is difficult because you become so invested with the children, notes that it can be so difficult and troubling when a student you have worked with and care about struggles, and how this can be especially severe if they actually go through something traumatic.

ref.speaker: Participant 13
ref.text:
Yeah, I would say that with crisis, you're much more responsible for people. I would speak to people, and then I would use that information to then decide, what do they need? Am I going to have them involuntarily hospitalize? Or am I going to send them home? Whatever happens falls on me. So there was a lot of training about how you deal with that.  And how do you cope with that?

Whereas school counseling is less pressure. We just kind of guide, and it is up to the students to do what they will. There is less responsibility for outcomes. Where there is less liability for their choices, you are way more invested with school counseling. With crises I would meet people once, mayber twice. And on the second time, that’s hard because you don’t want to meet them twice. With school counseling you are so much more invested. I have known people for months and I’m so invested I can’t imagine knowing them for 4 years, knowing people from freshman to senior year and then seeing them fail!?  Ugh! That would gut you. That’s just for nomal things they fail at. Not even for when actual trauma happens or actual hard things happen. You are so invested and in it and you feel like they are a part of you. They are an extension of your own children!

annotations.annotation: Participant 13 agrees that the high level of empathy and connection with the students impacts secondary trauma in that environment.

annotations.annotation: Participant 13 appreciated that the book dealt with specific mental health concepts and explained them very well – notes that this is particularly important for counselors who mostly don’t have a mental health background; notes that the book was helpful because it was not just generally informative but specific and directive; notes that it succeeded where other educational materials fall short in demonstrating how to use the information.

ref.speaker: Participant 13
ref.text:
I'll be honest. I haven't finished the book. I did start the book. I wanted it to be something. I finished by my internship, but the internship has more than enough going on. 

However, I really really like that it engages with specific mental health concepts. Because school counseling deals with mental health on the fringe. They are very clear that you may be a mental health support, but you are not a therapist. You aren’t there to use specific terminology, you are not there to help them figure out what they do or don’t have. That’s not what you are there for. You are there as a support to help with other mental health counselors like a therapist or case workers. I say that to say that I really like that this gives specifics, first of all. Because, I have mental training, but that’s me, I’m not all school counselors. School counselors in general come from an education background not a mental health background. So I like that this gives a lot of mental health specific information. Like here is what this word means, here is what it can look like. Here is what is can look like for students, or for yourself - mentally, physically, emotionally. Here is specfic information for that. And, here is how you can use that in your specific role. I think that was very very helpful. And I also liked first of all, that the book is really interactive. I’ll say that. It is different than sitting and reading a chapter book. I really like that it’s interactive and you can kind of apply it to your experiences or future experiences. 

I also liked that going along with the specific definitions and examples, I liked that there was always the application of here is how it could affect you. Here is how it could affect your students. And here is what to do with that information. Because I think lot of resources I’ve experienced so far miss that last step. A lot of things are information heavy: here is what you need to know!” And then I feel a lot of the times, what do I do with that though! I’ve identified that, cool…but now what!

annotations.annotation: Participant 13 notes that trainings like the ACES don’t provide application for the information. This is where the book succeeded.

ref.speaker: Morgan Cooley
ref.text:
Exactly. Sometimes that's how I feel about ACE’s training. I can empathize with that. The application is important right?

annotations.annotation: Participant 13 notes that the box did have an impact in raising her awareness towards the concept of vicarious trauma; notes that they weren’t expecting to apply the information they’d learned in previous crisis roles to this position, but now they are aware; notes that the box has really helped them understand this and that they are grateful that they learned this at the beginning of their career so they can approach their responsibilities with this awareness.

ref.speaker: Participant 13

Whereas someone like my site supervisor has been doing this for ten years and feels like “it hasn’t failed me yet” - so why would I change. So I think it has really helped with just being aware of how their experiences, hard experiences and even not that hard experiences -they don’t think it’s hard when they fail - being aware of how to manage myself in that. Knowing that I can’t shoulder all of their choices and their burdens and their responsibilities. And how even if I find myself doing it- what can I do then to stop it to revert it and to calm myself. annotations.annotation: Participant 13 notes that people who have been in the field for a long time are sometimes more resistant to new trainings and ideas and may be harder to introduce to the box; notes that the newer generations are open to new educational ideas and concepts.

ref.speaker: Participant 13
ref.text: Great question! To be fair…she's a unique character. A different conversation for a different time. [Her reaction] was not personal to the box. They’re a difficult person to move on anything. For somebody with a mental health background versus not, or just somebody that’s been doing it a long time versus somebody that hasn’t….The hard thing at least that I’ve seen so far and that I’ll probably continue to see is that people that have been doing this a long time since pre-covid, since pre-socio emotional learning, since pre ACEs training, since pre-All of that, have a very different mindset and perspective on kid’s beheavior and on their own behavior than those that started after all of that. At least people that are in my generation. But you can learn at any point. But people who are in my ‘school of learning’ - I guess - I’ve noticed are much more willing to learn and flexible. You are going to introduce a concept like ACEs and we’re like “that makes sense! yeah!” and then we kind of move forward. While people pre-all of that are just kind of like (scoffs), “I haven’t seen any of that” and kind of just dismiss it. So I say that to say - I don’t know if the box can attract them. I don’t know!

annotations.annotation: Participant 13 notes that a mental health box for counselors would be extremely helpful; notes that most counselors come from an education background and have virtually no mental health education; notes that while they build relationships with the students, they are very uncomfortable and unsure having conversations with students going through severe mental health issues and they often have no idea what to say; notes that this is even true for very seasoned and experienced counselors.

ref.speaker: Participant 13
ref.text: It’s funny that you say that because what I was going to say was probably a mental health box for counselors. Because pretty much all of the counselors at my old school at least came from education backgrounds. They were either teachers themselves or just had education degrees and moved into this, and don’t really have a lot of mental health training. They don’t really feel comfortable talking about mental health. They all know, for example, that if a student is struggling with suicidal thoughts, they know cognitively that they should say explicitly ‘are you having thoughts of killing yourself’ but none of them are comfortable saying it. None of them are comfortable actually having those thought conversations. So I did all of them! Because I was comfortable and I’ve done it 1000 times. I’ve had those hard conversations so many freakin times. I was the one, they’d always refer to me a lot. Like ‘what would you say to this person?’ Or ‘how would you go about this?’ A lot of different things! Eating disorders comes up a lot, and they don’t really know specific language to use. They know processes, if the student is a danger to themselves they know they have to tell mom. But they don’t know, what are the exact words I should say to this student, right now! They really struggle with that I think. And these are people who have been doing this for 7-10 years. They just really struggle with specific language to use when kids are struggling. When they say ‘I’m feeling depressed’ They struggle with what to say beyond ‘oh that sucks!’ They don’t really know what to specifically say!

annotations.annotation: Participant 13 thinks that a substance abuse box to might be necessary but might not be, because in their past school there was a substance use- specific counselor to which students were referred.

ref.speaker: Participant 13
ref.text: Yes and no. At least in my old school there is a DATA counselor (drug and alcohol). So if somebody says ‘I’m struggling with this” you just kind of support them as an authoritative role. And then just say “have you thought about that before? Have you thought about the consequences of those actions? I’m going to refer you to DATA” And then they go to Data.

annotations.annotation: Participant 13 notes that substance abuse can be a little simpler for counselors because they can be a little more direct and blunt with the students in a way you can’t with mental health issues

ref.speaker: Participant 13
ref.text: That one you can be a little more harsh I would say. You can say ‘you are making not smart choices here!’ Whereas you can’t really do that with mental health issues. Counselors have no problem being authoritative, I’ve seen. Of getting on to kids? They have no problem with that. I feel like with substance use they kind of need that kick in the but of like ‘why are you doing that!’ But with mental health you can’t really do that?

annotations.annotation: Participant 13 wonders whether counselors would open a box that helps them deal with parents and authority; notes that some (but not all) counselors struggle with either commiserating with parents or acting like they don’t see the issue at all.

ref.speaker: Participant 13
ref.text: I’m trying to think practically. Like if I put the box in front of the counselors at royal palm would they even open it? You know, a lot of them there approach in dealing with parernts or teachers is 1 of 2 routes. It’s either lamenting with them: ‘the student is awful. I know. That’s awful. I’m going to get you some help.’ Or it’s the extreme opposite, of like the gaslight-ey: ‘well I don’t see it at all! and I don’t have that issue! That’s not my job, I can’t do anything about it’ kind of thing. That’s not to say that nobody knows how to talk to parents or teachers. That’s not fair, but…

annotations.annotation: Participant 13 uses a consultation script from their graduate school (FAU) to deal with parents; notes that it is very helpful and specific, and that other counselors are always interested and impressed with it; notes that they seem to be interested but don’t actually end up using it.

ref.speaker: Participant 13
ref.text: So there is a consultation model that FAU teaches. It’s got a script and everything. It’s three pages long and you just follow through it. And there is questions to ask. And it’s the most helpful thing. And every single time that I used it, and my supervisor saw, she would ask me ‘what are you using, what is that?’ Every time. Every time somebody else saw it if I was using it with a teacher they would say ‘what are you using?’ I always got compliments on it. And I was always trying to share it! It’s not a secret! Anybody can use it! I’m literally just following a script. It’s so simple and it’s so intuitive. But even then they’d be like ‘oh that’s cool’ and like never look at it again.
